Scali]] | state6 = [[Texas]] | district6 = {{ushr|TX|7|7th}} | term_start6 = January 3, 1967 | term_end6 = January 3, 1971 | predecessor6 = [[John Dowdy]] | successor6 = [[Bill Archer]] | birth_name = George Herbert Walker Bush | birth_date = {{Birth date|1924|06|12}} | birth_place = [[Milton, Massachusetts]], U.S. | death_date = {{nowrap|{{Death date and age|2018|11|30|1924|06|12}}}} | death_place = [[Houston, Texas]], U.S. | resting_place = [[George Bush Presidential Library]] | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | spouse = {{Marriage|[[Barbara Bush|Barbara Pierce]]|1945|2018|reason=died}} | relatives = ''See [[Bush family]]'' | children = {{hlist|[[George W. Bush|George]]|[[Pauline Robinson Bush|Robin]]|[[Jeb Bush|Jeb]]|[[Neil Bush|Neil]]|[[Marvin Bush|Marvin]]|[[Dorothy Bush Koch|Dorothy]]}} | parents = {{Plainlist| * [[Prescott Bush]] * Dorothy Walker }} | education = [[Yale University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]]) | signature = George HW Bush Signature.svg | signature_alt = Cursive signature in ink | website = {{URL|bushlibrary.tamu.edu|Presidential Library}} | allegiance = {{flagu|United States|1912|size=23px}} | branch = {{flag|United States Navy|1864|size=23px}} | serviceyears = 1942–1945 | rank ={{Dodseal|USNO3|25}} [[Lieutenant (junior grade)]] | unit = [[Fast Carrier Task Force]] | battles = [[World War II]] | mawards = {{Plainlist| * [[File:Distinguished Flying Cross ribbon.svg|border|23px]] [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] * [[File:Air Medal ribbon.svg|border|23px]] [[Air Medal]] * [[File:United States Navy Presidential Unit Citation ribbon.svg|border|23px]] [[Presidential Unit Citation (United States)|Presidential Unit Citation]]}} }} {{George H. W. Bush series}} '''George Herbert Walker Bush''' (June 12, 1924 – November 30, 2018) was an [[American politician]] who served as the 41st [[President of the United States]] from 1989 to 1993. Prior to assuming the presidency, Bush served as the 43rd [[Vice President of the United States]] from 1981 to 1989. As a member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]], he had previously been a [[U.S. Representative]], Ambassador, and [[Director of Central Intelligence]]. During his career in [[public service]], he was known simply as George Bush; after his eldest son [[George W. Bush]] became President of the United States in 2001, he was referred to as "George H. W. Bush", "Bush 41", or "George Bush Sr."
A scion of the [[Bush family]], he was born in [[Milton, Massachusetts]], to [[Prescott Bush]] and Dorothy Walker Bush. Following the [[attack on Pearl Harbor]] on December 7, 1941, Bush postponed his university studies, enlisted in the [[United States Navy]] on his 18th birthday, and became one of the youngest [[Naval aviation|aviator]]s in the U.S. Navy. He served until September 1945, and then attended [[Yale University]]. Graduating in 1948, he moved his family to [[West Texas]], where he entered the [[oil business]] and became a millionaire by the age of 40 in 1964.
Soon after founding his own oil company, Bush became involved in politics. He was defeated in his first election, for the U.S. Senate [[United States Senate election in Texas, 1964|in 1964]], but won election to the House of Representatives from [[Texas's 7th congressional district|Texas's 7th district]] [[United States House of Representatives elections, 1966#Texas|in 1966]]. He was re-elected in 1968 but was defeated for election to the Senate again [[United States Senate election in Texas, 1970|in 1970]]. In 1971, President [[Richard Nixon]] appointed Bush as [[United States Ambassador to the United Nations|Ambassador to the United Nations]], and in 1973, Bush became the [[Chairman of the Republican National Committee]]. The following year, President [[Gerald Ford]] appointed Bush as [[List of ambassadors of the United States to China#List of Chiefs of the U.S. Liaison Office in Beijing|Chief of the Liaison Office]] in [[China]] and later made Bush the [[Director of Central Intelligence]]. Bush ran for president in [[1980 United States presidential election|1980]] and was defeated in the [[1980 Republican Party presidential primaries|Republican primary]] by [[Ronald Reagan]], who chose him as his running mate in his successful bid for presidency. During his eight-year tenure as Vice President, Bush headed task forces on deregulation and the [[war on drugs]].
Bush ran [[George H. W. Bush presidential campaign, 1988|a successful campaign]] in [[1988 United States presidential election|1988]], defeating [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] opponent [[Michael Dukakis]], becoming the first [[incumbent]] vice president in 152 years to be elected president. [[Foreign policy]] drove the [[Presidency of George H. W. Bush|Bush presidency]]: [[Military operation]]s were conducted in [[United States invasion of Panama|Panama]] and [[Gulf War|the Persian Gulf]]; the [[Berlin Wall]] fell in 1989, and the [[Soviet Union]] dissolved two years later. Bush also signed the [[North American Free Trade Agreement]] (NAFTA), which created a [[trade bloc]] consisting of the United States, [[Canada]], and [[Mexico]]. Domestically, Bush [[Read my lips: no new taxes|reneged on a 1988 campaign promise]] and signed a bill to increase taxes. In the wake of a weak recovery from an [[Early 1990s recession|economic recession]] and the diminution of foreign policy as a major issue in a post-[[Cold War]] [[political climate]], he lost the [[1992 United States presidential election|1992 presidential election]] to Democrat [[Bill Clinton]].
After leaving office in 1993, Bush was active—often alongside his former opponent [[Bill Clinton]]—in humanitarian activities. With George W. Bush's victory in the 2000 presidential election, Bush and his son became the second father–son pair to serve as president, following [[John Adams]] and [[John Quincy Adams]]. Bush's second son, [[Jeb Bush]], served as the [[List of Governors of Florida|43rd]] Governor of Florida and sought the Republican presidential nomination in 2016.
Bush [[Death and state funeral of George H. W. Bush|died]] on November 30, 2018, at the age of {{Age in years and days nts|1924|06|12|2018|11|30}}. He has the distinction of being the [[List of presidents of the United States by age|longest-lived president]] in American history. <!-- If Jimmy Carter is still alive on March 21, 2019, change the final sentence to: At the time of his death he was the [[List of presidents of the United States by age|longest-lived president]] in American history, a record surpassed by Jimmy Carter on March 21, 2019. -->
==Early life and education== {{See also|Bush family}} [[File:George H W Bush at Age One and One-Half, ca 1925.gif|thumb|left|upright|George H. W. Bush, c. 1925<!-- And yes we know there is a piece of broccoli in his hand, please don't mention here that he hates it as it is too trivial -->]]
George Herbert Walker Bush was born at 173 Adams Street in [[Milton, Massachusetts]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.presidentialavenue.com/gb.cfm |title=Presidential Avenue: George Bush |access-date=March 29, 2008 |publisher=Presidential Avenue|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071008144507/http://www.presidentialavenue.com/gb.cfm|archive-date=October 8, 2007|dead-url=yes}}</ref> on June 12, 1924, to [[Prescott Bush|Prescott Sheldon Bush]] and Dorothy (Walker) Bush. The Bush family moved from Milton to [[Greenwich, Connecticut]], shortly after his birth. Bush was named after his maternal grandfather, George Herbert Walker, who was known as "Pop". In turn, Bush was called "Poppy" as a tribute to his namesake.<ref>{{cite web |author=Eun Kyung Kim |url=http://www.today.com/parents/jenna-bush-hager-welcomes-second-daughter-named-after-george-h-t31121 |title=Jenna Bush Hager welcomes second daughter — named after George H.W. Bush |website=[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today]] |date=August 14, 2015 |quote=The new bundle of joy is named after Jenna's grandfather and former President George H.W. Bush, whose nickname growing up was "Poppy."}}</ref>
Bush began his formal education at the [[Greenwich Country Day School]] in Greenwich. Beginning in 1938, he attended [[Phillips Academy]] in [[Andover, Massachusetts]], where he held a number of leadership positions that included president of the senior class, secretary of the student council, president of the community fund-raising group, a member of the editorial board of the school newspaper, and captain of both the varsity baseball and soccer teams.<ref name="andover">{{cite web |url=http://www.andover.edu/news/bush.htm |title=Former President George Bush honored at his 60th reunion at Phillips Academy, Andover |date=June 8, 2002 |access-date=March 29, 2008 |publisher=Phillips Academy |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080401131455/http://www.andover.edu/news/bush.htm |archivedate=April 1, 2008 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>
===World War II=== [[File:George Bush being rescued by the submarine, the U.S.S. Finback, after being shot down while on a bombing run of the... - NARA - 186382.tif|thumb|upright|Crewmen of the submarine USS ''Finback'' rescue Bush]]
The United States formally entered World War II in December 1941, following [[Empire of Japan|Japan]]'s surprise [[attack on Pearl Harbor]] in Hawaii. Six months later, Bush enlisted into the [[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]]<ref name="navy">{{cite web |url=https://www.history.navy.mil/content/history/nhhc/research/histories/biographies-list/bios-b/bush-george-h-w.html |title=George Herbert Walker Bush |date=December 1, 2018 |access-date=December 2, 2018 |publisher=Navy History and Heritage Command}}</ref> immediately after he graduated from [[Phillips Academy]] on his eighteenth birthday. He became a [[Naval aviation|naval aviator]], taking training for [[aircraft carrier]] operations aboard [[USS Sable (IX-81)|USS ''Sable'']].<ref name="andover" /><ref>{{cite web |last= |first= |authorlink= |vauthors= |title=The Greater Buffalo & The U.S.S. Sable |website= |publisher=WNY Heritage Press |year=2005 |url=https://www.wnyheritage.org/content/the_greater_buffalo_the_uss_sable/index.html |doi= |access-date=July 25, 2017}}</ref> After completing the 10-month course, he was commissioned as an [[Ensign (rank)|ensign]] in the [[United States Navy Reserve|United States Naval Reserve]] at [[Naval Air Station Corpus Christi]] on June 9, 1943 (just three days before his 19th birthday), which made him one of the youngest [[Naval aviation|aviator]]s in the U.S. Navy.<ref name="navy" />
In September 1943, he was assigned to Torpedo Squadron 51 (VT-51) as the photographic officer.<ref name="navy" /> The following year, his squadron was based in {{USS|San Jacinto|CVL-30|6}} as a member of Air Group 51, where his lanky physique earned him the nickname "Skin".<ref name="Skin">{{cite news |url=http://hamptonroads.com/2009/01/san-jacinto-veterans-reunite-recall-serving-bush |title=San Jacinto veterans reunite, recall the one they called 'Skin' |last=Adams |first=Kathy |date=January 10, 2009 |work=The Virginian-Pilot |publisher=Landmark Communications |access-date=January 10, 2009}}</ref> During this time, the task force was victorious in one of the largest air battles of World War II: the [[Battle of the Philippine Sea]].<ref name="navy" />
[[File:George H.W. Bush seated in a Grumman TBM Avenger, circa 1944 (H069-13).jpg|thumb|left|upright|Bush in his Grumman TBM Avenger aboard USS ''San Jacinto'' in 1944]]
After Bush's promotion to [[lieutenant (junior grade)]] on August 1, 1944, ''San Jacinto'' commenced operations against the Japanese in the [[Bonin Islands]]. Bush piloted one of four [[Grumman TBF Avenger|Grumman TBM Avenger]]s of VT-51 that attacked the Japanese installations on [[Chichijima]].<ref>"[http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0312/20/cp.00.html Story of George H. W. Bush World War II Experience]". [[CNN]]. December 20, 2003.</ref> His crew for the mission, which occurred on September 2, 1944, included Radioman Second Class John Delaney and Lt.(jg) William White.<ref name="navy" /> Although his aircraft was hit by [[flak]] during the attack, Bush successfully released bombs and scored several hits.<ref name="navy" /> With his engine ablaze, Bush flew several miles from the island, where he and one other crew member bailed out;<ref name="maam" /> the other man's [[parachute]] did not open.<ref name="navy" /> Bush waited for four hours in an inflated raft, while several fighters circled protectively overhead, until he was rescued by the submarine {{USS|Finback|SS-230|6}}.<ref name="navy" /> For the next month, he remained in ''Finback'' and participated in the rescue of other aviators. Several of those shot down during the attack were executed, and their livers were [[Chichijima incident|eaten]] by their captors.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Bradley |first1=James | authorlink = James Bradley (author)|title=Flyboys: A True Story of Courage |date=2003 |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |isbn=978-0-316-10584-2|title-link=Flyboys: A True Story of Courage }}</ref> This experience shaped Bush profoundly, leading him to ask, "Why had I been spared and what did God have for me?"<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.christianpost.com/news/the-faith-of-george-h-w-bush-189108/ |title=The Faith of George HW Bush}}</ref>
In November 1944, Bush returned to ''San Jacinto'' and participated in operations in the Philippines until his squadron was replaced and sent home to the United States. Through 1944, he flew 58 combat missions<ref name="maam">{{cite web |url=http://www.maam.org/flightsim/news/tbm_history.htm |title=History's Youngest Naval Aviator: George H. W. Bush |publisher=Mid-Atlantic Air Museum |access-date=March 29, 2008}}</ref> for which he received the [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)|Distinguished Flying Cross]], three [[Air Medal]]s, and the [[Presidential Unit Citation (United States)|Presidential Unit Citation]] awarded to ''San Jacinto''.<ref name="navy" /> Bush was then reassigned to a training wing for torpedo bomber crews at [[Naval Station Norfolk|Norfolk Navy Base]], Virginia. His final assignment was to a new torpedo squadron, VT-153, based at [[Naval Air Station Grosse Ile]], Michigan. Bush was [[Military discharge|honorably discharged]] from the U.S. Navy in September 1945, one month after the [[Victory over Japan Day|surrender of Japan]].<ref name=GHWBlifebefore>{{cite web |title=George H. W. Bush: Life Before the Presidency |last=Knott |first=Stephen |url=https://millercenter.org/president/bush/life-before-the-presidency |publisher=Miller Center, the University of Virginia |location=Charlottesville, Virginia |access-date=April 24, 2018|date=October 4, 2016}}</ref>
==Marriage and college years== When Bush was still in the Navy, he married [[Barbara Bush|Barbara Pierce]] (1925–2018) in [[Rye, New York]] on January 6, 1945.<ref>{{cite web |last=Markovich |first=Jeremy |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/01/george-hw-bush-and-barbara-pierce-are-wed-jan-6-1945-233101 |title=George H.W. Bush and Barbara Pierce are wed: Jan. 6, 1945 |publisher=Politico |date=January 6, 2017 |access-date=November 17, 2017}}</ref> The marriage produced six children: [[George W. Bush|George W.]] (b. 1946), [[Pauline Robinson Bush|Robin]] (1949–1953), [[Jeb Bush|Jeb]] (b. 1953), [[Neil Bush|Neil]] (b. 1955), [[Marvin Bush|Marvin]] (b. 1956), and [[Dorothy Bush Koch|Doro]] (b. 1959).<ref name=GHWBlifebefore /> At the time of his wife's death on April 17, 2018, George H. W. had been married to Barbara for 73 years; theirs was the longest presidential marriage in American history.<ref>{{cite news |last=Siegel |first=Rachel |date=April 22, 2018 |title='You were the reason': Barbara and George Bush's love story remembered at her funeral |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/retropolis/wp/2018/04/22/you-were-the-reason-barbara-and-george-bushs-historic-love-story-hailed-at-her-funeral/?noredirect=on&utm_term=.f62542cad2a1 |work=The Washington Post |access-date=November 30, 2018}}</ref> They had become the longest-married presidential couple in 2000 when their marriage surpassed the 54-year (1764–1818) marriage of [[John Adams|John]] and [[Abigail Adams]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Camia |first=Catalina |date=January 6, 2015 |title=George and Barbara Bush celebrate 70th anniversary |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2015/01/06/george-and-barbara-bush-70-anniversary/21344481/ |work=USA Today |access-date=November 30, 2018}}</ref>
After Bush received his military discharge, he enrolled at [[Yale University]]. He earned an undergraduate degree in economics on an accelerated program that enabled him to graduate in two and a half years, rather than the usual four.<ref name=GHWBlifebefore /> He was a member of the [[Delta Kappa Epsilon]] fraternity and was elected its president.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/12/books/41-george-w-bushs-portrait-of-george-h-w-bush.html |title=Love Flows, President to President |newspaper=The New York Times |date=November 11, 2014 |first=Michiko |last=Kakutani |access-date=November 14, 2014}}</ref> He also captained the Yale baseball team and played in the first two [[College World Series]] as a left-handed [[first baseman]].<ref>{{cite web |title=School House to White House: The Education of the Presidents |url=https://www.archives.gov/publications/prologue/2007/spring/schoolhouse.html |date=Spring 2007 |publisher=National Archives |location=Washington, D.C. |access-date=March 29, 2008}}</ref> Bush was the team captain during his senior year in 1948, and he met [[Babe Ruth]] before a game; the event took place only weeks before Ruth's death. Like his father, he was also a member of the Yale cheerleading squad.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://yaledailynews.com/blog/2008/01/28/cheerleading-of-the-20s-epitome-of-masculinity/ |title=Cheerleading of the '20s: Epitome of masculinity |work=Yale Daily News |first=Simone |last=Berkower |access-date=July 30, 2016}}</ref> Late in his junior year, he was initiated into the [[Skull and Bones]] [[secret society]]; his father [[Prescott Bush]] had been initiated into the same society in 1917. He was elected to [[Phi Beta Kappa]] when he graduated from Yale in 1948 with a Bachelor of Arts degree in economics.<ref name="cnn">{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/SPECIALS/cold.war/kbank/profiles/bush/ |title=George Herbert Walker Bush |publisher=CNN |access-date=March 29, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080308132103/http://www.cnn.com/SPECIALS/cold.war/kbank/profiles/bush/ |archivedate=March 8, 2008 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>
==Business career== After graduating from Yale, Bush moved his young family to [[West Texas]]. His father's business connections proved useful as he ventured into the oil business, starting as an [[Petroleum reservoir#Oil field|oil field]] equipment salesman<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2005/oct/11/local/me-bush11 |title=Two Future Presidents Slept Here — latimes |publisher=Articles.latimes.com |date=October 11, 2005 |access-date=May 17, 2017|newspaper=Los Angeles Times |last1=Chawkins |first1=Steve}}</ref> for [[Dresser Industries]], a subsidiary of [[Brown Brothers Harriman & Co.]], where Prescott Bush had served on the board of directors for 22 years.<ref name="ea">{{cite web |url=http://198.181.165.52/article?assetid=0068080-00&templatename=/article/article.html |title=Bush, George Herbert Walker |access-date=March 29, 2008 |publisher=Scholastic Library Publishing, Inc |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080615195838/http://198.181.165.52/article?assetid=0068080-00&templatename=%2Farticle%2Farticle.html |archivedate=June 15, 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=}}</ref> While working for Dresser, Bush lived in various places with his family: [[Odessa, Texas]]; [[Ventura, California|Ventura]], [[Bakersfield, California|Bakersfield]] and [[Compton, California]]; and [[Midland, Texas]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://bush41library.tamu.edu/archives/finding-aids/donated-materials/george-bush#zapata_oil |title=George Bush Collection |work=George Bush Presidential Library and Museum |access-date=July 30, 2016}}</ref> (According to eldest son [[George W. Bush]], then age two, the family lived in one of the few duplexes in Odessa with an indoor bathroom, which they "shared with a couple of hookers".)<ref>George W. Bush interview with [[Bob Schieffer]] on ''[[Face the Nation]]'' (aired November 9, 2014)</ref> Bush started the Bush-Overbey Oil Development company in 1951 and in 1953 co-founded the [[HRG Group|Zapata Petroleum Corporation]], an oil company that drilled in the [[Permian Basin (North America)|Permian Basin]] in Texas.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://law.jrank.org/pages/4940/Bush-George-Herbert-Walker.html |title=George Herbert Walker Bush |publisher=Net Industries |access-date=March 29, 2008}}</ref> In 1954, he was named president of the Zapata Offshore Company, a subsidiary which specialized in [[offshore drilling]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Perin |first=Monica |date=April 25, 1999 |title=Adios, Zapata! |url=https://www.bizjournals.com/houston/stories/1999/04/26/story2.html |work=[[American City Business Journals|Houston Business Journal]] |access-date=November 30, 2018}}</ref>
Shortly after the subsidiary became independent in 1959, Bush moved the company and his family from [[Midland, Texas|Midland]] to [[Houston]].<ref>Bush, George W. ''41: A Portrait of My Father.'' Crown Publishers, 2014, p. 64.</ref> He continued serving as president of the company until 1964, and later chairman until 1966, when he won election to the U.S. House of Representatives.<ref name="ea" /> By that time, Bush had become a millionaire.<ref name="msn">{{cite encyclopedia |url=http://encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761571000/George_H_W_Bush.html |title=George Herbert Walker Bush |access-date=March 29, 2008 |publisher=MSN Encarta |archivedate=November 1, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5kwpnrBU3?url=http://encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761571000/George_H_W_Bush.html |deadurl=yes}}</ref>
==Early political career (1963–1980)== ===Congressional years (1967–1971)=== [[File:George H. W. Bush 91st Congress.jpg|thumb|Bush in 1969]]
Bush's career in politics began in 1963 when he was elected chairman of the [[Harris County, Texas]] Republican Party. The following year, he ran against incumbent Democrat [[Ralph Yarborough|Ralph W. Yarborough]] in the [[United States Senate election in Texas, 1964|U.S. Senate race]]. He presented himself as a young Conservative Republican in contrast to the aging liberal Democrat Yarborough. He campaigned against civil rights legislation pending before Congress, stating that he believed it gave too much power to the federal government.<ref name=GHWVB>{{cite book |last=Naftali |first=Timothy |date=2007 |title=George H. W. Bush |work=The American Presidents Series| editor1-last=Schlesinger, Jr.| editor1-first=Arthur M.| editor2-last=Wilentz| editor2-first=Sean |url=https://books.google.com/?id=VDm1ov1wUhoC&pg=PA13&lpg=PA13 |isbn=978-0-8050-6966-2 |publisher=Times Books, Henry Holt and Company |location=New York City |access-date=April 20, 2018}}</ref> Bush lost the election 56% to 44%,<ref>{{cite book |last=Meacham |first=Jon |title=Destiny and Power: The American Odyssey of George Herbert Walker Bush |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iMgOCAAAQBAJ&pg=PT147 |year=2015 |publisher=Random House |pages=117–122 |isbn=9780812998207}}</ref> though he did outpoll Republican presidential nominee [[Barry Goldwater]], who lost by an overwhelming margin to [[Lyndon B. Johnson]].<ref name="GHWVB" />
Bush and the Harris County Republicans played a role in the development of the new Republican Party of the late 20th century. First, Bush worked to absorb the [[John Birch Society]] members, who were trying to take over the Republican Party. Second, during and after the [[civil rights movement]], Democrats in the South who were committed to [[racial segregation|segregation]] left their party, and although the "country club Republicans" had differing ideological beliefs, they found common ground in hoping to expel the Democrats from power.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/americanexperience/features/transcript/bush-transcript/ |title=Program Transcript. George H. W. Bush. WGBH, American Experience |publisher=PBS |access-date=August 13, 2012}}</ref>
[[File:George Herbert Walker Bush and Eisenhower 1.jpg|thumb|left|Former President [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]] with Bush]]
In 1966, Bush was elected to a seat in the [[United States House of Representatives]] from the [[Texas's 7th congressional district|7th District of Texas]]; he won 57 percent of the ballots cast in a race against Democrat Frank Briscoe, who was the district attorney of Harris County.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=47440 |title=TX District 07 |publisher=Our Campaigns |access-date=March 19, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/article/Ex-DA-Frank-Briscoe-legal-heavyweight-for-1689920.php |title=Ex-DA Frank Briscoe, legal heavyweight for decades, dies at 84, January 5, 2011 |work=[[Houston Chronicle]] |access-date=March 9, 2014|date=January 5, 2011}}</ref> Bush was the first Republican to represent Houston in the U.S. House.<ref name="ea" /> Bush's representative district included [[Tanglewood, Houston|Tanglewood]], the Houston neighborhood that was his residence;<ref name=Hickey>Hickey, Elisabeth. "[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=WT&p_theme=wt&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB0EFD27A57641B&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D Bushes' lot: No room for real estate]". ''[[The Washington Times]]''. Thursday November 19, 1992. Part E Life E1. Accessed on [[LexisNexis]].</ref> his family had moved into Tanglewood in the 1960s.<ref name=Feldman>{{cite news |last=Feldman |first=Claudia |url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl?id=1992_1099189 |title=Moving back to the 'hood .../CITIZEN BUSH |work=[[Houston Chronicle]] |date=December 13, 1992 |page=Lifestyle p. 1 |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://archive.is/20121208154849/http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl?id=1992_1099189 |archive-date=December 8, 2012 |df=}}</ref> His voting record in the House was generally [[Conservatism in the United States|conservative]]: Bush voted for the [[Civil Rights Act of 1968]], although it was generally unpopular in his district. He supported the [[Presidency of Richard Nixon|Nixon administration]]'s [[Vietnam War|Vietnam policies]], but broke with Republicans on the issue of [[birth control]], which he supported.<ref name="ea" /> Despite being a first-term congressman, Bush was appointed to the powerful [[United States House Committee on Ways and Means]], where he voted to abolish the [[Conscription|military draft]].<ref name="msn" /> He was elected to a second term in 1968.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=180430 |title=TX District 7 |publisher=Our Campaigns |access-date=March 19, 2008}}</ref>
In 1970, Nixon convinced Bush to relinquish his House seat in order to [[United States Senate election in Texas, 1970|run for the Senate]] against Ralph Yarborough, who was a fierce Nixon critic. In the Republican primary, Bush easily defeated conservative [[Robert J. Morris]] by a margin of 87.6% to 12.4%.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=278800 |title=TX US Senate – R Primary |publisher=Our Campaigns |access-date=March 19, 2008}}</ref> Nixon went to [[Longview, Texas]], to campaign for Bush and gubernatorial candidate [[Paul Eggers]], a [[Dallas]] lawyer who was a close friend of U.S. Senator [[John Tower|John G. Tower]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/index.php?pid=2776 |title="Richard Nixon: Remarks at Longview, Texas", October 28, 1970 |publisher=presidency.ucsb.edu |access-date=November 29, 2009}}</ref> Former Congressman [[Lloyd Bentsen]], a more moderate Democrat and native of [[Mission, Texas|Mission]] in south Texas, defeated Yarborough in the Democratic primary.<ref name="msn" /> Yarborough endorsed Bentsen, who went on to defeat Bush, 53.4 to 46.6%.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=6529 |title=TX US Senate |publisher=Our Campaigns |access-date=March 19, 2008}}</ref>
===Ambassador to the United Nations (1971–1973)=== [[File:George Bush as United Nations Representative, 1971-72 - NARA - 186386.tif|thumb|Bush as ambassador to the United Nations, 1971]] Following his 1970 loss, Bush was well known as a prominent Republican businessman from the "[[Sun Belt]]", a group of states in the Southern part of the country.<ref name="msn" /> Nixon noticed and appreciated the sacrifice Bush had made of his Congressional position,<ref name="ea" /> so he appointed him [[United States Ambassador to the United Nations]].<ref name="cnn" /> He was confirmed unanimously by the Senate, and served for two years, beginning in 1971.<ref name="ea" />
His ambassadorship was marked by a notable defeat on the China question. On October 25, 1971, the General Assembly voted to expel the [[Republic of China]] and replace it with the People's Republic of China.<ref name="nytimes19711031">{{cite news |last1=Austin |first1=Anthony |title=Crushing Defeat for the U.S., or A Blessing In Disguise? |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1971/10/31/archives/crushing-defeat-for-the-us-or-a-blessing-in-disguise-enter-peking.html |work=The New York Times |date=October 31, 1971 |language=en}}</ref> Bush was hissed when he got up to speak, and the delegates cheered and danced after defeating a US motion to require a two-thirds [[supermajority]].<ref name="nytimes_obituary"/> The resolution then won a two-thirds supermajority anyway, as the United States lost the support of every [[NATO]] country.<ref name="nytimes19711031"/> Although Bush condemned the "gladiatorial ugliness" of the debate,<ref name="nytimes_obituary"/> he advocated friendly relations with the Chinese delegation.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Szulc |first1=Tad |title=Correct but Relaxed Dealings With Chinese Urged by Bush |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1971/11/09/archives/correct-but-relaxed-dealings-with-chinese-urged-by-bush.html |work=The New York Times |date=November 9, 1971 |language=en}}</ref> Two months later, Bush even placed himself in the position of depending on a Chinese veto in the [[United Nations Secretary-General selection, 1971|1971 Secretary-General selection]]. However he did not tell the Chinese, who unexpectedly abstained and allowed [[Kurt Waldheim]] to be selected as the next [[Secretary-General of the United Nations]].<ref name="frus247">{{cite encyclopedia|encyclopedia=United Nations, 1969–1972 |series=Foreign Relations of the United States, 1969–1976 |volume=Volume V |editor-last=Duncan |editor-first=Evan M. |year=2004 |location=Washington |publisher=United States Government Printing Office |title=Telegram From the Mission to the United Nations to the Department of State, December 22, 1971, 0356Z |url=https://history.state.gov/historicaldocuments/frus1969-76v05/d247 Document 247}}</ref>
===Chairman of the Republican National Committee (1973–1974)=== After [[Bob Dole]] resigned as chairman of the [[Republican National Committee]] in 1972, Nixon named Bush to the position.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Charlton |first1=Linda |title=Dole Quits as G.O.P. Head; Bush Named as Successor |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1972/12/12/archives/dole-quits-as-gop-head-bush-named-as-successor-dole-quits-as-gop.html |work=The New York Times |date=December 12, 1972 |language=en}}</ref><ref name="cnn"/> Bush took over in January 1973 and held this position as the [[Watergate scandal]] grew more damaging to Nixon.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nixon.archives.gov/thelife/apolitician/thepresident/index.php |title=The President (Richard Nixon) |publisher=Richard Nixon Presidential Library |access-date=March 29, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080327035848/http://nixon.archives.gov/thelife/apolitician/thepresident/index.php|archive-date=March 27, 2008|dead-url=yes}}</ref> He initially defended Nixon steadfastly, but as Nixon's complicity became clear he focused more on defending the Republican Party. As chairman, Bush formally requested that Nixon eventually resign for the good of the Republican party.<ref name="ea" /> Nixon did this on August 9, 1974; Bush noted in his diary that "There was an aura of sadness, like somebody died... The [resignation] speech was vintage Nixon—a kick or two at the press—enormous strains. One couldn't help but look at the family and the whole thing and think of his accomplishments and then think of the shame... [President Gerald Ford's swearing-in offered] indeed a new spirit, a new lift."<ref name="bushdiary">{{cite news |url=https://www.usnews.com/usnews/news/articles/060716/16bushonnixon_eye.htm |title=George HW on Nixon resignation |date=July 16, 2006 |access-date=March 29, 2008 |work=US News and World Report |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080624230333/http://www.usnews.com/usnews/news/articles/060716/16bushonnixon_eye.htm |archivedate=June 24, 2008}}</ref>
===Head of U.S. Liaison Office in China (1974–1975)=== [[File:George Bush as United States Liaison to China, 1974-1975 - NARA - 186378.tif|thumb|upright=0.7|left|Bush as U.S. Liaison to China, circa 1975]] President [[Gerald Ford]] appointed Bush to be Chief of the [[De facto embassy#China and the United States|U.S. Liaison Office]] in the [[China|People's Republic of China]]. Since the United States maintained diplomatic relations with the [[Republic of China|Republic of China (Taiwan)]] instead of the People's Republic of China, Bush did not hold the [[diplomatic rank]] of ambassador. However, Bush acted like an ambassador anyway, ignoring instructions from [[Henry Kissinger]] to stay away from diplomatic functions.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Bush |first1=George H. W. |editor-last1=Engel |editor-first1=Jeffrey A. |title=The China Diary of George H.W. Bush: The Making of a Global President |date=2011 |publisher=Princeton University Press |isbn=9781400829613 |page=36}}</ref> The 14 months that he spent in China were seen as beneficial for [[China–United States relations]].<ref name="ea"/>
After Ford assumed the presidency, Bush was under serious consideration for being nominated as vice president. Ford eventually narrowed his list to [[Nelson Rockefeller]] and Bush. [[White House Chief of Staff]] [[Donald Rumsfeld]] reportedly preferred Rockefeller over Bush. Rockefeller was finally named and confirmed.<ref name="senate">{{cite web |url=https://www.senate.gov/artandhistory/history/resources/pdf/george_bush.pdf |format=PDF |title=Vice Presidents of the United States: George H. W. Bush (1981–1989) |publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office |author=Hatfield, Mark (with the Senate Historical Office) |location=Washington, D.C. |year=1997 |access-date=November 4, 2015}}</ref> Ford again passed over Bush when he chose [[Bob Dole]] to replace Rockefeller on the 1976 presidential ticket.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Dowd |first1=Maureen |date=November 28, 1988 |title=Will Bush and Dole End Their Grand Old Rivalry? |page=A1 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/11/28/us/will-bush-and-dole-end-their-grand-old-rivalry.html |work=The New York Times |access-date=November 30, 2018}}</ref>
===Director of Central Intelligence (1976–1977)=== [[File:CIA Director George H.W. Bush listens at a meeting following the assassinations in Beirut, 1976 - NARA - 7064954.jpg|thumb|Bush, as CIA Director, listens at a meeting following the assassinations in Beirut of [[Francis E. Meloy Jr.]] and [[Robert O. Waring]], 1976.]] In 1976 Ford brought Bush back to Washington to become [[Director of Central Intelligence]] (DCI), replacing [[William Colby]].<ref name="TMNK">{{Cite AV media |people=Carl Colby (director) |date=September 2011 |title=The Man Nobody Knew: In Search of My Father, CIA Spymaster William Colby |url=http://firstrunfeatures.com/themannobodyknew/ |medium=Motion picture |publisher=Act 4 Entertainment |location=New York City |access-date=October 10, 2011 |time= |isbn= |ref=September 15, 2011}}</ref> He served in this role for 357 days, from January 30, 1976, to January 20, 1977.<ref name="ciabushinfo">{{cite web |url=https://www.cia.gov/about-cia/todays-cia/george-bush-center-for-intelligence/index.html |title=The George Bush Center for Intelligence |work=Central Intelligence Agency |date=April 5, 2007 |access-date=September 5, 2011}}</ref> The [[Central Intelligence Agency]] (CIA) had been rocked by a series of revelations, including those based on investigations by the [[Church Committee]] regarding illegal and unauthorized activities by the CIA, and Bush was credited with helping to restore the agency's morale.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.u-s-history.com/pages/h2025.html |title=Presidents: George H. W. Bush, 41st President of the United States |publisher=U-S-History.com |access-date=March 29, 2008}}</ref> In his capacity as DCI, Bush gave national security briefings to [[Jimmy Carter]] both as a presidential candidate and as president-elect, and discussed the possibility of remaining in that position in a Carter administration,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cia.gov/library/center-for-the-study-of-intelligence/csi-publications/books-and-monographs/cia-briefings-of-presidential-candidates/cia-8.htm |title=CIA Briefings of Presidential Candidates; Chapter 5: In-Depth Discussions With Carter |publisher=Central Intelligence Agency: Center for the Study of Intelligence |access-date=October 11, 2007}}</ref> but did not do so. He was succeeded by Deputy Director of Central Intelligence [[E. Henry Knoche]], who served as acting Director of Central Intelligence until [[Stansfield Turner]] was confirmed.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/08/28/AR2010082803203.html |work=The Washington Post |first=T. Rees |last=Shapiro |title=E. Henry Knoche, 85; a key player in the intelligence game |date=August 29, 2010}}</ref>
During Bush's year in charge of the CIA, the U.S. national security apparatus actively supported [[Operation Condor]] operations and right-wing [[military dictatorship]]s in [[Latin America–United States relations|Latin America]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Where Gerald Ford Went Wrong |url=http://baltimorechronicle.com/2007/010207Parry.shtml |work=The Baltimore Chronicle |date=2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=FIFA's Dirty Wars |url=https://newrepublic.com/article/146303/fifas-dirty-wars |work=The New Republic |date=December 15, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Quand Pinochet tuait hors du Chili |url=https://www.lexpress.fr/actualite/monde/amerique-sud/quand-pinochet-tuait-hors-du-chili_491779.html |work=L'Express |date=October 30, 1999}}</ref>
===Other positions (1977–1981)=== After Democrat [[Jimmy Carter]] took power in 1977, Bush became chairman on the Executive Committee of the [[First International Bank]] in Houston.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.presidentialtimeline.org/html/timeline.php?id=41 |access-date=July 30, 2016 |publisher=Presidential Timeline of the Twentieth Century |title=George H. W. Bush |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080503064357/http://www.presidentialtimeline.org/html/timeline.php?id=41 |archive-date=May 3, 2008}}</ref> He later spent a year as a part-time professor of Administrative Science at [[Rice University]]'s [[Jesse H. Jones Graduate School of Business|Jones School of Business]] beginning in 1978, the year it opened; Bush said of his time there, "I loved my brief time in the world of academia."<ref name="kiev">{{cite web |url=http://kiev.usembassy.gov/files/georgehwbush_speech_May04_eng.html |title=President George H. W. Bush: Kyiv National Taras Shevchenko University |date=May 21, 2004 |access-date=March 29, 2008 |publisher=Ukrainian Embassy |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080519115716/http://kiev.usembassy.gov/files/georgehwbush_speech_May04_eng.html |archivedate=May 19, 2008 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> Between 1977 and 1979, he was a director of the [[Council on Foreign Relations]] foreign policy organization.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cfr.org/about/history/cfr/appendix.html |title=The Council on Foreign Relations from 1921 to 1996 – Historical Roster of Directors and Officers}}</ref>
==1980 presidential campaign== {{See also|1980 United States presidential election}} [[File:Bush80.gif|thumb|right|1980 campaign logo]] Bush decided in the late 1970s that he was going to run for president in 1980; in 1979, he attended 850 political events ("[[Audition|cattle calls]]") and traveled more than {{convert|250000|mi|km}} to campaign for the nation's highest office. In the contest for the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] nomination, Bush stressed his wide range of government experience, while competing against rivals Senator [[Howard Baker]] of Tennessee, Senator [[Bob Dole]] of Kansas, Congressman [[John B. Anderson|John Anderson]] of Illinois (who would later run as an independent), Congressman [[Phil Crane]], also of Illinois, former Governor [[John Connally]] of Texas, former Minnesota Governor [[Harold Stassen]], and the front-runner [[Ronald Reagan]], a noted former actor and the former [[Governor of California]].<ref name="senate" />
[[File:Reagan-Bush Nashua 1980 debate.jpg|thumb|left|Ronald Reagan, moderator John Breen, and Bush participate in the Nashua, New Hampshire Presidential Debate, 1980]] At the outset of the [[1980 Republican Party presidential primaries|1980 primary race]], Bush focused heavily on winning the January 21 [[Iowa caucuses]], including 31 visits to the state; five months earlier he had won the [[Iowa Straw Poll]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Noble |first=Jason |date=November 30, 2018 |title=George H.W. Bush in Iowa: The family campaign |url=https://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/news/politics/2018/11/30/george-bush-died-iowa-caucuses-obituary/545814002/ |work=[[The Des Moines Register]] |access-date=December 1, 2018}}</ref> Reagan, however, far ahead in the polls, campaigned little. Bush represented the centrist wing in the GOP, whereas Reagan represented conservatives. Bush famously labeled Reagan's [[supply-side economics|supply side]]-influenced plans for massive [[tax cut]]s "[[Reaganomics|voodoo economics]]".<ref>{{cite news |last=Neikirk |first=William R. |date=March 13, 1988 |title=Bush conjures up voodoo economics |url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-1988-03-13-8802290552-story.html |work=Chicago Tribune |access-date=December 1, 2018}}</ref> His strategy proved useful, to some degree, as he won in Iowa with 31.5% to Reagan's 29.4%. After the win, Bush stated that his campaign was full of momentum, or "[[the Big Mo]]".<ref>{{cite news |last=Quinn |first=Ken |date=January 18, 2004 |title=Caucus-goers gave Bush 'Big Mo' |page=A15 |work=Des Moines Register |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15854185/caucusgoers_gave_bush_big_mo/ | via=[[Ancestry.com#Newspapers.com|Newspapers.com]] |access-date=December 1, 2018}} {{free access}}</ref>
As a result of the loss, Reagan replaced his [[campaign manager]], reorganized his staff, and concentrated on the [[New Hampshire primary]]. The two men agreed to a debate in the state, organized by ''[[The Telegraph (Nashua)|The Nashua Telegraph]]'', but paid for by the Reagan campaign. Reagan invited the other four candidates as well, but Bush refused to debate them, and eventually they left. The debate proved to be a pivotal moment in the campaign; when the moderator, John Breen, ordered Reagan's microphone turned off, his angry response, "I am paying for this microphone," struck a chord with the public. Bush ended up losing New Hampshire's primary with 23% to Reagan's 50%. Bush lost most of the remaining primaries as well, and formally dropped out of the race in May of that year.<ref name="senate" />
With his political future in doubt, Bush sold his house in Houston and bought his grandfather's estate in [[Kennebunkport, Maine|Kennebunkport]], Maine, known as "Walker's Point".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/07/08/us/white-house-letter-at-parents-home-bush-resumes-role-of-son.html|work=The New York Times |access-date=April 2, 2008 |date=July 8, 2002 |last=Bumiller |first=Elisabeth |title=White House Letter; At Parents' Home, Bush Resumes Role of Son}}</ref> At the [[1980 Republican National Convention|Republican Convention]], Reagan made the last-minute decision to select Bush as his vice presidential nominee, placing him on the winning [[1980 United States presidential election|Republican presidential ticket of 1980]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Allen |first=Richard V. |date=July 30, 2000 |title=George Herbert Walker Bush; The Accidental Vice President |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/07/30/magazine/george-herbert-walker-bush-the-accidental-vice-president.html |work=The New York Times |access-date=November 30, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Cannon |first1=Lou |last2=Broder |first2=David S. |date=July 17, 1980 |title=Reagan Nominated, Picks Bush |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1980/07/17/reagan-nominated-picks-bush/a1badab9-a12b-4e7f-86a2-1bde75e03346/?noredirect=on&utm_term=.1a4d799ce2a2 |work=The Washington Post |access-date=December 1, 2018}}</ref>
==Vice presidency (1981–1989)== {{See also|Presidency of Ronald Reagan}}
===First term, 1981–1985=== As vice president, Bush generally maintained a typically low profile while he recognized the constitutional limits of the office; he avoided decision-making or criticizing Reagan in any way. As had become customary, he and his wife moved into the Vice President's residence at [[Number One Observatory Circle]], about two miles from the [[White House]]. After selling the house in [[Tanglewood, Houston|Tanglewood]], the Bushes declared a room in [[The Houstonian Hotel]] in [[Houston]] as their official voting address.<ref name=Hickey /> The Bushes attended a large number of public and ceremonial events in their positions, including many [[state funeral]]s, which became a common joke for comedians. Mrs. Bush found the funerals largely beneficial, saying, "George met with many current or future heads of state at the funerals he attended, enabling him to forge personal relationships that were important to President Reagan." As the [[Vice President of the United States#Roles of the vice president|President of the Senate]], Bush stayed in contact with members of Congress and kept the president informed on occurrences on Capitol Hill.<ref name="senate" />
[[File:Vice President George H. W. Bush portrait.jpg|thumb|150px|left|Vice President Bush official portrait (1981)]] On March 30, 1981 (early into the administration), [[Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan|Reagan was shot]] and seriously wounded by [[John Hinckley Jr.]] in Washington, D.C. Bush was in [[Fort Worth, Texas]], and immediately flew back to Washington D.C. because he was next in line to the presidency. Reagan's cabinet convened in the White House [[Situation Room]], where they discussed various issues, including the availability of the "[[nuclear football]]". When Bush's plane landed, he was advised by his aides to proceed directly to the White House by helicopter as an image of the government still functioning despite the attack. Bush rejected the idea, responding, "Only the President lands on the South Lawn."<ref name="senate" /> This made a positive impression on Reagan,<ref name="senate" /> who recovered and returned to work within two weeks. From then on, the two men would have regular Thursday lunches in the [[Oval Office]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Bumiller |first=Elisabeth |date=June 9, 2004 |title=The 40th President: Between 2 First Families, A Complicated Rapport |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/06/09/us/40th-president-presidential-relations-between-2-first-families-complicated.html |work=The New York Times |access-date=November 30, 2018}}</ref>
[[File:Photograph of the Official Portrait of President Reagan and Vice-President Bush - NARA - 198518.jpg|thumb|President [[Ronald Reagan]] with Bush]]
In November 1982, Bush toured [[Africa]], the first instance of a high United States government official visiting the continent since the Reagan administration began. Bush told reporters that while he would allow for heads of state to dictate how each meeting would transpire, there was an expectation on his part for discussions on the independence of [[Namibia]], adding that the United States was going to retain the position of no settlement in Namibia until Cuban troops in [[Angola]] were withdrawn.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1982/11/10/Vice-President-George-Bush-acting-as-the-presidents-personal/4018405752400/ |title=Vice President George Bush, acting as the president's personal... |first=Jim |last=Anderson |date=November 10, 1982 |publisher=UPI}}</ref> On November 15, Bush met with [[United States Secretary of State]] [[George P. Shultz]] and [[Yuri Andropov]] in Moscow, Russia, to discuss human rights and arms reductions. Bush later said, "The meeting was frank, cordial and substantive. It gave both sides the opportunity to exchange views on the state of their relations."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1982/11/15/Vice-President-George-Bush-and-Secretary-of-State-George/2659406184400/ |title=Vice President George Bush and Secretary of State George... |first=Steven R. |last=Reed |date=November 15, 1982 |publisher=UPI}}</ref>
At the end of January 1983, Bush began a seven-day tour of [[Western Europe]] intended to promote the arms reduction commitment being advocated for by the Reagan administration.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/31/world/bush-starts-7-nation-trip-in-bonn-aim-is-to-reassure-allies-on-arms.html |title=Bush Starts 7-Nation Trip In Bonn; Aim Is To Reassure Allies On Arms |date=January 31, 1983 |first=James M. |last=Markham |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> During a February 8 news conference in Paris, Bush said the United States' invitations for the Soviet Union to consent to a reduction in medium-range missiles were supported by Western Europe, which he stated had also consented to the deployment of new American missiles starting in the latter part of the year.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/09/world/bush-in-paris-says-allies-commitment-on-missiles-remains-firm.html |title=Bush, In Paris, Says Allies' Commitment On Missiles Remains Firm |first=John |last=Vinocur |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> The following day, Bush defended American nuclear arms policy when answering British Secretary General of the Committee on Nuclear Disarmament [[Bruce Kent]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/10/world/bush-in-london-challenged-by-nuclear-foe.html |title=Bush, In London, Challenged By Nuclear Foe |first=John |last=Vinocur |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref>
In September 1983, Bush met with [[President of Romania]] [[Nicolae Ceaușescu]], insisting during the meeting that President Reagan intended to push for arms reductions at the Geneva talks with the Soviet Union.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1983/09/18/Vice-President-George-Bush-met-Sunday-with-President-Nicholae/1371432705600/ |title=Vice President George Bush met Sunday with President Nicholae... |first=Cathy |last=Booth |date=September 18, 1983 |publisher=UPI}}</ref> Shortly thereafter, Bush said the United States wanted better relations with all countries within the [[Eastern Bloc]] though he stressed that NATO would retaliate in the event of any threatening of European military stability by the Soviets,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1983/09/19/Vice-President-George-Bush-Monday-praised-Communist-Hungarys-human/2242432792000/ |title=Vice President George Bush Monday praised Communist Hungary's human... |first=Ruth E. |last=Gruber |publisher=UPI}}</ref> and the vice president assailed the Soviet Union for the [[Berlin Wall]] and destroying the [[Korean Airlines Flight 007|Korean Air Lines jetliner]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1983/09/21/Vice-President-George-Bush-today-accused-the-Soviet-Union/1835432964800/ |title=Vice President George Bush today accused the Soviet Union... |first=Ruth E. |last=Gruber |date=September 21, 1983 |publisher=UPI}}</ref>
[[File:C17903-4.jpg|thumb|left|Reagan and Bush in a meeting to discuss the [[United States invasion of Grenada|United States' invasion of Grenada]] with a group of bipartisan members of [[United States Congress|Congress]] in October 1983]] In December 1983 Bush flew to [[El Salvador]] and warned that country's military leaders to end their [[death squad]]s and hold fully free elections or face the loss of U.S. aid. "It is not just the President, it is not just me or the Congress. If these death-squad murders continue, you will lose the support of the American people and that would indeed be a tragedy."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/12/world/in-salvador-bush-assails-death-squads.html |title=In Salvador, Bush Assails Death Squads |first=Lydia |last=Chavez |date=December 12, 1983 |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> Bush's aides feared for his safety and thought about calling the meeting off when they discovered apparent blood stains on the floor of the presidential palace of [[Álvaro Magaña]]. Bush was never told of the aides' concerns and a tense meeting was held in which some of Magaña's personnel brandished semiautomatic weapons and refused requests to take them outside.<ref name=nowimp>{{cite web |last=Solomon |first=John |url=http://www.newsweek.com/2011/03/20/a-wimp-he-wasn-t.html |title=A Wimp He Wasn't |work=Newsweek |date=March 20, 2011 |access-date=May 22, 2011}}</ref>
Bush was assigned by Reagan to chair two special task forces, on [[deregulation]] and international drug smuggling. The deregulation task force reviewed hundreds of rules, making specific recommendations on which ones to amend or revise, in order to curb the size of the federal government. The drug smuggling task force coordinated federal efforts to reduce the quantity of drugs entering the United States. Both were popular issues with conservatives, and Bush, largely a moderate, began courting them through his work.<ref name="senate" />
On June 14, 1984, Bush cast a tie-breaking vote in the Senate in favor of the 10-warhead [[LGM-118 Peacekeeper|MX missile system]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1984/06/14/Vice-President-George-Bush-cast-a-dramatic-tie-breaking-vote/3222456033600/ |title=Vice President George Bush cast a dramatic, tie-breaking vote... |first=Eliot |last=Brenner |date=June 14, 1984 |publisher=UPI}}</ref>
===Second term, 1985–1989=== [[File:Photograph of President Reagan and Vice-President Bush meeting with General Secretary Gorbachev on Governor's Island... - NARA - 198596.jpg|thumb|International policy with the [[Soviet Union]] was a critical component of the political landscape in the late 1980s. Vice President Bush can be seen here standing with President [[Ronald Reagan]] and Soviet leader [[Mikhail Gorbachev]], on the New York City waterfront, 1988]] Reagan and Bush [[1984 United States presidential election|ran for reelection in 1984]]. Their [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] opponent, [[Walter Mondale]], made history by choosing a woman, New York Representative [[Geraldine Ferraro]], as his running mate. She and Bush squared off in [[United States vice-presidential debate, 1984|a single televised vice presidential debate]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/showdebate.php?debateid=27 |title=Bush-Ferraro Vice-Presidential Debate |date=October 11, 1984 |access-date=April 3, 2008 |publisher=The American Presidency Project |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080617164446/http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/showdebate.php?debateid=27 |archivedate=June 17, 2008 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> Ferraro served as a contrast to the Ivy-League educated Bush; she represented a [[Blue-collar worker|blue-collar]] district in [[Queens]], New York. This distinction and her popularity among female journalists left Bush at a disadvantage. Regardless, the Reagan-Bush ticket won in a landslide against the Mondale-Ferraro ticket. Early into his second term as vice president, Bush and his aides were planning a run for the presidency in 1988. By the end of 1985, a committee had been established and over two million dollars were raised for Bush.<ref name="senate" />
On July 13, 1985, Bush became the first vice president to serve as [[Acting President of the United States|acting president]] when Reagan underwent surgery to remove [[polyp (medicine)|polyps]] from his [[Large intestine|colon]]; Bush served as the acting president for approximately eight hours.<ref>{{cite news |last=Boyd |first=Gerald M. |date=July 14, 1985 |title=Reagan Transfers Power to Bush For 8-Hour Period of 'Incapacity' |page=A1 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/07/14/us/reagan-transfers-power-to-bush-for-8-hour-period-of-incapacity.html |work=The New York Times |access-date=November 30, 2018}}</ref>
In 1986, the Reagan administration was shaken by a scandal when it was revealed that administration officials had secretly arranged weapon sales to Iran. The officials had used the proceeds to fund the anti-communist [[Contras]] in Nicaragua, which was a direct violation of law. The scandal became known as the [[Iran–Contra affair]]. When news of the public embarrassment broke to the media, Bush, like Reagan, stated that he had been "out of the loop" and unaware of the diversion of funds,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/97/06/29/reviews/iran-transcript.html |title=Transcript |work=The New York Times |date=June 30, 1997 |access-date=April 2, 2008 |format=fee required}}</ref> although this was later questioned.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gwu.edu/~nsarchiv/NSAEBB/NSAEBB210/index.htm |title=The Iran-Contra Affair 20 Years On |date=November 20, 2006 |access-date=April 3, 2008 |publisher=George Washington University}}</ref> His diaries from that time stated "I'm one of the few people that know fully the details" and as a result of six pardons by Bush, the independent counsel's final report on the Iran–Contra affair pointedly noted: "The criminal investigation of Bush was regrettably incomplete."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gwu.edu/~nsarchiv/NSAEBB/NSAEBB210/index.htm |title=The Iran-Contra Affair 20 Years On |publisher=Gwu.edu |access-date=January 16, 2012}}</ref>
In March 1986, Bush outlined the government's policy on the combating of terrorism. In an interagency task force report presented to President Reagan, Bush publicly stated that the strategy of the federal government was to retaliate without "wantonly" terminating human lives.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/03/07/world/bush-issuing-terror-report-affirms-current-us-policies.html |title=Bush, Issuing Terror Report, Affirms Current U.S. Policies |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=March 7, 1986}}</ref>
In May 1986, Bush underwent a procedure to remove a malignant growth from his left cheek. His spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said that doctors had found the growth weeks earlier.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/05/18/us/bush-has-malignancy-removed-from-cheek.html |title=Bush Has Malignancy Removed From Cheek |date=May 18, 1986 |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> [[File:Margaret Thatcher George H.W. Bush 1986.jpg|thumb|British Prime Minister [[Margaret Thatcher]] and Bush, 1986]]
In September 1987, Bush embarked on a month long trip to [[Poland]] and European allied countries.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1987/08/18/Vice-President-George-Bush-announced-Tuesday-he-will-travel/8055556257600/?spt=su |title=Vice President George Bush announced Tuesday he will travel... |date=August 18, 1987 |publisher=UPI}}</ref> On September 22, Bush cast a tie breaking vote in the Senate to save the Strategic Defense Initiative from receiving a 800 million cut in funding.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1987/09/22/Vice-President-George-Bush-cast-a-rare-tie-breaking-vote/6250559281600/ |title=Vice President George Bush cast a rare tie-breaking vote... |date=September 22, 1987 |publisher=UPI}}</ref> On September 28, Bush delivered a televised address pledging that the US would forever be aligned with Poland.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1987/09/28/Vice-President-George-Bush-engaged-in-an-extraordinary-public/9779559800000/ |title=Vice President George Bush engaged in an extraordinary public... |first=Norman D. |last=Sandler |publisher=UPI |date=September 28, 1987}}</ref>
On July 3, 1988, the [[Cruiser#Late 20th century|guided missile cruiser]] {{USS|Vincennes|CG-49|6}} accidentally shot down [[Iran Air Flight 655]], killing 290 passengers. Bush said that he would "never apologize for the United States of America. Ever. I don't care what the facts are."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-fix/wp/2013/11/08/when-should-a-president-say-hes-sorry/ |title=When should a president say he's sorry? |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=November 8, 2013 |first=Scott |last=Wilson}}</ref>
==1988 presidential campaign== {{Main|1988 United States presidential election}} [[File:Bushquayle1988.gif|thumb|Campaign logo]] [[File:Gwbush1988stl.jpg|thumb|[[John Ashcroft]] and Vice President Bush campaign in St. Louis, Missouri, 1988]]
As early as 1985, Bush had been planning a presidential run; he entered the Republican primary for President of the United States in October 1987.<ref name="senate" /> His challengers for the Republican presidential nomination included U.S. Senator [[Bob Dole]] of [[Kansas]], U.S. Representative [[Jack Kemp]] of New York, former Governor [[Pete du Pont]] of [[Delaware]], and conservative Christian [[Televangelism|televangelist]] [[Pat Robertson]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Shogan |first=Robert |date=February 9, 1988 |title=Politics 88 : Dole, Gephardt Win; Bush Third : Robertson Is a Surprise 2nd in GOP Polling |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1988-02-09/news/mn-41620_1_george-bush |work=Los Angeles Times |access-date=November 30, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Dionne Jr. |first=E. J. |date=February 9, 1988 |title=Dole Wins in Iowa, With Robertson Next |page=A1 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/02/09/us/dole-wins-in-iowa-with-robertson-next.html |work=The New York Times |access-date=November 30, 2018}}</ref>
Bush was considered the early frontrunner for the nomination, but he came in third in the Iowa caucus, behind winner Dole and runner-up Robertson.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/02/10/us/bush-and-simon-seen-as-hobbled-by-iowa-s-voting.html |title=Bush and Simon Seen as Hobbled by Iowa's Voting |date=February 10, 1988 |access-date=April 4, 2008 |work=The New York Times |first=R. W. |last=Apple Jr. |authorlink=R. W. Apple Jr.}}</ref> Much as Reagan had done in 1980, Bush reorganized his staff and concentrated on the New Hampshire primary.<ref name="senate" /> With Dole ahead in New Hampshire, Bush ran television commercials portraying the senator as a tax raiser;<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.history.com/minisite.do?content_type=Minisite_Generic&display_order=1&content_type_id=57687&mini_id=57351 |title=New Hampshire: Picking a President |publisher=The History Channel |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080424102704/http://www.history.com/minisite.do?content_type=Minisite_Generic&display_order=1&content_type_id=57687&mini_id=57351 |archivedate=April 24, 2008 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> he rebounded to win the state's primary. Following the primary, Bush and Dole had a joint media appearance, when the interviewer asked Dole if he had anything to say to Bush, Dole said, in response to the ads, "yeah, stop lying about my record!" in an angry tone. This is thought to have hurt Dole's campaign to Bush's benefit. Bush continued seeing victory, winning many Southern primaries as well.<ref name="ea" /> Once the multiple-state primaries such as [[Super Tuesday]] began, Bush's organizational strength and fundraising lead were impossible for the other candidates to match, and the nomination was his.<ref name="msn" />
As the [[1988 Republican National Convention]] approached, there was much speculation who Bush would choose to be his running mate. He selected little-known U.S. Senator [[Dan Quayle]] of [[Indiana]], who was favored by conservatives. Despite Reagan's popularity, Bush trailed Democratic nominee [[Michael Dukakis]], then [[Governor of Massachusetts]], in most polls.<ref name="npr">{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/news/national/election2000/conventions/past.bushsenior.html |title=1988: George H. W. Bush Gives the 'Speech of his Life' |publisher=NPR |year=2000 |access-date=April 4, 2008}}</ref>
Bush was occasionally criticized for his lack of eloquence when compared to Reagan, but he delivered a well-received speech at the 1988 Republican National Convention. Known as the "[[thousand points of light]]" speech, the presentation described Bush's vision of America. He endorsed the [[Pledge of Allegiance]], [[Capital punishment in the United States|capital punishment]], and [[Right to keep and bear arms in the United States|gun rights]], and drew upon his long-standing Christian beliefs to support both [[school prayer|prayer in schools]] and [[United States anti-abortion movement|oppose abortion]].<ref name="npr" /> The speech at the convention included Bush's famous pledge: "[[Read my lips: no new taxes]]."<ref name="bbc">{{cite news |publisher=[[BBC News]] |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/november/9/newsid_3655000/3655368.stm |title=1988: Bush wins with 'no new taxes' promise |access-date=April 4, 2008 |date=November 9, 1988}}</ref>
[[File:ElectoralCollege1988.svg|thumb|left|The 1988 presidential electoral votes by state]] The general election campaign between the two men was described in 2008 as one of the dirtiest in modern times.<ref name="bbc" /> Bush blamed Dukakis for polluting the [[Boston Harbor]] as the Governor of Massachusetts.<ref name="ea" /> Bush also pointed out that Dukakis was opposed to a law that would require all students to say the Pledge of Allegiance, a topic well covered in Bush's nomination acceptance speech.<ref name="npr" />
Dukakis's unconditional opposition to capital punishment led to a pointed question being asked during the presidential debates. Moderator [[Bernard Shaw (journalist)|Bernard Shaw]] asked Dukakis if he would hypothetically support the death penalty if his wife, [[Kitty Dukakis|Kitty]], were raped and murdered.<ref name="kittyd">{{cite web |url=http://www.debates.org/pages/trans88b.html |title=The Second Bush-Dukakis Presidential Debate |date=October 13, 1988 |publisher=[[Commission on Presidential Debates]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080406032116/http://www.debates.org/pages/trans88b.html |archivedate=April 6, 2008 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> Dukakis's response of no, as well as a provocative ad about convicted felon [[Willie Horton]], contributed toward Bush's characterization of Dukakis as "soft on crime".<ref name="ea" />
Bush defeated Dukakis and his running mate, [[Lloyd Bentsen]], in the [[United States Electoral College|Electoral College]], by 426 to 111 (Bentsen received one vote from a [[faithless elector]]).<ref name="bbc" /> In the nationwide popular vote, Bush took 53.4% of the ballots cast while Dukakis received 45.6%.<ref name="ea" /> Bush became the first serving vice president to be elected president since [[Martin Van Buren]] in 1836 as well as the first person to succeed someone from his own party to the presidency via election to the office in his own right since [[Herbert Hoover]] in 1929.<ref name="senate" />
==Presidency (1989–1993)== {{Main|Presidency of George H. W. Bush}} [[File:George H. W. Bush inauguration.jpg|thumb|Chief Justice [[William Rehnquist]] administers the Presidential Oath of Office to George H. W. Bush during his January 20, 1989 inauguration ceremony at the [[United States Capitol]]]]
Bush was [[Inauguration of George H. W. Bush|inaugurated]] on January 20, 1989, succeeding Ronald Reagan. He entered office at a period of change in the world; the fall of the [[Berlin Wall]] came early in his presidency, and the collapse of the [[Soviet Union]] came in 1991.<ref name="white house bio">{{cite book |last1=Freidel |first1=Frank |last2=Sidey |first2=Hugh |title=The Presidents of the United States of America |date=2006 |publisher=White House Historical Association|chapter-url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/1600/presidents/georgehwbush |access-date=February 15, 2017 |chapter=George H. W. Bush}}</ref> He ordered military operations in [[United States invasion of Panama|Panama]] and the [[Gulf War|Persian Gulf]], and, at one point, was recorded as having a record-high approval rating of 89%.<ref>Gallup, George W.''The Gallup Poll: Public Opinion, 1991'', Published 1992, Rowman & Littlefield</ref>
In his Inaugural Address, Bush said: {{Quote | style=font-size: 100%; |I come before you and assume the Presidency at a moment rich with promise. We live in a peaceful, prosperous time, but we can make it better. For a new breeze is blowing, and a world refreshed by freedom seems reborn; for in man's heart, if not in fact, the day of the dictator is over. The [[Totalitarianism|totalitarian]] era is passing, its old ideas blown away like leaves from an ancient, lifeless tree. A new breeze is blowing, and a nation refreshed by freedom stands ready to push on. There is new ground to be broken, and new action to be taken.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bushlibrary.tamu.edu/research/papers/1989/89012000.html |title=George H. W. Bush: Inaugural Address |publisher=Bushlibrary.tamu.edu |date=January 20, 1989 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040420073736/http://bushlibrary.tamu.edu/research/papers/1989/89012000.html |archivedate=April 20, 2004}}</ref>}}
===Domestic policy===
====Economy==== {{Infobox U.S. Cabinet | align = right | Name = Bush | President = George H. W.
