===Awards and honors=== In 1990, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]] ''magazine named him the [[Time Person of the Year|Man of the Year]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Church |first=George J. |date=January 7, 1991 |title=A Tale of Two Bushes |url=http://content.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2030812_2030725_2030636,00.html |work=Time |access-date=November 30, 2018}}</ref> In 1991, the U.S. Navy Memorial Foundation awarded Bush its Lone Sailor award for his naval service and his subsequent government service.<ref>{{cite news |last=Conconi |first=Chuck |date=February 1, 1991 |title=Personalities |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1991/02/01/personalities/bd23cfac-9e1b-4eab-b4e9-3c800f30bb21/?noredirect=on&utm_term=.965bc2eaf751 |work=The Washington Post |access-date=November 30, 2018}}</ref> In 1993, he was made an Honorary [[Order of the Bath|Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath]] by Queen Elizabeth II.<ref name="Honours: Order of the Bath">{{cite web |url=http://www.royal.gov.uk/output/page4883.asp |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080530062826/http://www.royal.gov.uk/output/page4883.asp |archivedate=May 30, 2008 |title=Honours: Order of the Bath |publisher=The British Monarchy Today |access-date=March 28, 2008}}</ref> In 2009, he received the [[PGA Tour Lifetime Achievement Award]] and was inducted into the [[World Golf Hall of Fame]] two years later.<ref>{{cite news |date=September 22, 2010 |title=Ernie Els, George H.W. Bush among inductees to golf hall of fame |url=https://latimesblogs.latimes.com/sports_blog/2010/09/ernie-els-george-hw-bush-among-inductees-to-golf-hall-of-fame.html |work=Los Angeles Times |access-date=November 30, 2018}}</ref>
===1992 presidential campaign=== {{Main|1992 United States presidential election}} In early 1992, Bush announced that he would seek a second term. A coalition victory in the Persian Gulf War and high approval ratings made re-election seem likely. As a result, many leading Democrats declined to seek their party's presidential nomination.<ref>{{cite news |last=Kornacki |first=Steve |date=April 10, 2011 |title=The Mario Effect: Last time a group of presidential challengers was this unimpressive, there was a reason |url=https://www.politico.com/states/new-york/albany/story/2011/04/the-mario-effect-last-time-a-group-of-presidential-challengers-was-this-unimpressive-there-was-a-reason-067223 |work=[[Politico]] |access-date=December 1, 2018}}</ref> On the negative side, Bush's popularity was reduced by an economic recession and doubts of whether he properly ended the Gulf War.<ref>{{cite news |last=Kagay |first=Michael R. |date=May 22, 1991 |title=History Suggests Bush's Popularity Will Ebb |page=A18 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/22/us/history-suggests-bush-s-popularity-will-ebb.html |work=The New York Times |access-date=December 1, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Greenhouse |first=Steven |date=May 11, 1992 |title=The Economy; Despite Recession's End, Bush May Face Unusually Harsh Public Judgment |page=B8 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/05/11/us/1992-campaign-economy-despite-recession-s-end-bush-may-face-unusually-harsh.html |work=The New York Times |access-date=December 1, 2018}}</ref>
Conservative political columnist [[Pat Buchanan]] challenged Bush for the Republican nomination. He shocked political pundits by finishing second, with 37% of the vote in the New Hampshire primary. Bush responded by adopting more conservative positions on issues, in an attempt to undermine Buchanan's base.<ref name="msn" /> Once he had secured the nomination, Bush faced his Democratic challenger, [[List of Governors of Arkansas|Arkansas Governor]] [[Bill Clinton]]. Clinton attacked Bush as a politician who was not doing enough to assist the working middle-class and being "out of touch" with the common man, a notion reinforced by reporter [[Andrew Rosenthal]]'s false report that Bush was "astonished" to see a demonstration of a supermarket [[barcode reader|scanner]].<ref name=Goldberg08 /><ref name="snopes">{{cite web |url=http://www.snopes.com/history/american/bushscan.htm |title=Maybe I'm Amazed |date=April 1, 2001 |access-date=April 11, 2008 |publisher=Snopes.com |archivedate=May 27, 2012 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120527030747/http://www.snopes.com/history/american/bushscan.asp |deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref name=Rosenthal92 />
[[File:ElectoralCollege1992.svg|upright=1.35|thumb|The 1992 presidential electoral votes by state]] In early 1992, the race took an unexpected twist when Texas billionaire [[Ross Perot|H. Ross Perot]] launched a third party bid, claiming that neither Republicans nor Democrats could eliminate the deficit and make government more efficient. His message appealed to voters across the political spectrum disappointed with both parties' perceived fiscal irresponsibility.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Perot Vote |publisher=President and Fellows of Harvard College |access-date=April 23, 2008 |url=http://www.hks.harvard.edu/case/3pt/perot_vote.html}}</ref> Perot later bowed out of the race for a short time, then reentered.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/10/27/us/the-1992-campaign-the-independent-bush-aide-calls-perot-s-story-paranoid.html |title=The 1992 Campaign: The Independent; Bush aide calls Perot's story 'paranoid' |date=October 27, 1992 |access-date=April 14, 2008 |work=The New York Times |last=Holmes |first=Steven A}}</ref>
Clinton had originally been in the lead, until Perot reentered, tightening the race significantly.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/10/25/us/1992-campaign-overview-contest-tightens-perot-resurges-clinton-slips.html |title=The 1992 Campaign: The Overview; Contest tightens as Perot resurges and Clinton slips |access-date=April 14, 2008 |date=October 25, 1992 |work=The New York Times |last=Toner |first=Robin}}</ref> As Election Day neared, the polls suggested that the race was a dead-heat,<ref name="ea" /> but Clinton pulled out on top, with 370 electoral votes to Bush's 168 votes. Perot won 19% of the popular vote, one of the highest totals for a third party candidate in U.S. history, drawing equally from both major candidates, according to exit polls.<ref name="msn" /><ref>{{cite news |last=Holmes |first=Steven A. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/11/05/us/1992-elections-disappointment-analysis-eccentric-but-no-joke-perot-s-strong.html |title=The 1992 Elections: Disappointment – News Analysis An Eccentric but No Joke; Perot's Strong Showing Raises Questions On What Might Have Been, and Might Be |work=The New York Times |date=November 5, 1992 |access-date=September 5, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://millercenter.org/academic/americanpresident/bush/essays/biography/3 |title=George Herbert Walker Bush: Campaigns and Elections |access-date=April 11, 2008 |publisher=Miller Center of Public Affairs |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080409120342/http://millercenter.org/academic/americanpresident/bush/essays/biography/3 |archivedate=April 9, 2008}}</ref>
Several key factors led to Bush's defeat. The ailing economy that arose from recession may have been the main factor in Bush's loss. On Election Day, 7 in 10 voters said that the economy was either "not so good" or "poor".<ref>{{cite news |first=R. W. |last=Apple Jr. |authorlink=R. W. Apple Jr.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/11/04/us/the-1992-elections-news-analysis-the-economy-s-casualty.html|title=The 1992 Elections: News Analysis; The Economy's Casualty |work=The New York Times |date=November 4, 1992 |access-date=September 5, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.sfgate.com/health/article/Downside-of-Reagan-legacy-2714909.php |title=Downside of the Reagan Legacy |work=The San Francisco Chronicle |access-date=April 11, 2008 |last=Lazarus |first=David |date=June 9, 2004}}</ref> On the eve of the 1992 election, after unemployment reports of 7.8% appeared (the highest since 1984),<ref>{{cite journal |author=WSJ Research |year=2015 |journal=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |title=How the Presidents Stack Up: A Look at U.S. Presidents' Job Approval Ratings (George H.W. Bush) |url=https://www.wsj.com/public/resources/documents/info-presapp0605-31.html |access-date=November 4, 2015}}</ref> Economic [[recession]] had contributed to a sharp decline in his approval rating – to just 37%.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pollingreport.com/whitejk.htm |title=Presidency on Life Support |publisher=Pollingreport.com |access-date=September 5, 2010}}</ref>
Conservative Republicans pointed out that Bush's 1990 agreement to raise taxes contradicted his famous "[[Read my lips: no new taxes]]" pledge. In doing so, Bush alienated many members of his conservative base, losing their support for his re-election. According to one survey, of the voters who cited Bush's broken "No New Taxes" pledge as "very important", two thirds voted for Bill Clinton.<ref>{{cite news |first=Jeffrey |last=Schmalz |title=Clinton Carves a Path Deep Into Reagan Country |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0CEFD8173FF937A35752C1A964958260 |work=The New York Times |date=November 4, 1992 |access-date=May 21, 2008}}</ref> Bush had raised taxes in an attempt to address an increasing budget deficit, which has largely been attributed to the Reagan tax cuts and military spending of the 1980s. The tax revenue increase had not hurt his approval rating to the extent that it prevented it from reaching its highest level, 89%, by February 1991, during the [[Gulf War]], and four months after the tax vote.<ref>[http://www.tnr.com/blog/plank/110499/the-illusory-power-grover-norquist The Illusory Power of Grover Norquist], Timothy Noah, November 27, 2012</ref><ref>[http://www.gallup.com/poll/116677/presidential-approval-ratings-gallup-historical-statistics-trends.aspx Presidential Approval Ratings – Gallup Historical Statistics and Trends], Gallup.com</ref>
===Public image=== [[File:US Navy 051008-N-9274T-001 After arriving on board Naval Air Station Joint Reserve Base (NAS JRB), New Orleans, former President George H. Bush sits down to eat with military personnel.jpg|thumb|Bush visits [[Naval Air Station Joint Reserve Base New Orleans|NAS JRB]], New Orleans personnel before he receives briefs on the status of [[Joint Task Force Katrina]] relief efforts, October 2005]] George Bush was widely seen as a "pragmatic caretaker" president who lacked a unified and compelling long-term theme in his efforts.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/presidents/george-h-w-bush-1482924.html |title=The Independent — George H. W. Bush |work=The Independent |location=UK |date=January 22, 2009 |access-date=September 5, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/54609/michael-howard/the-prudence-thing-george-bush-s-class-act |title=The Prudence Thing: George Bush's Class Act |issue=November/December 1998 |journal=Foreign Affairs |date=November 1, 1998 |access-date=September 5, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,963342-2,00.html |work=Time |title=Where Is the Real George Bush? |date=January 26, 1987 |access-date=May 3, 2010 |first=Robert |last=Ajemian}}</ref> Indeed, Bush's [[sound bite]] where he refers to the issue of overarching purpose as "the vision thing" has become a metonym applied to other political figures accused of similar difficulties.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.askoxford.com/worldofwords/quotations/phrasefable/visionthing/?view=uk |title=Quotations : Oxford Dictionaries Online |publisher=Askoxford.com |access-date=July 30, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030204213218/http://www.askoxford.com/worldofwords/quotations/phrasefable/visionthing/?view=uk |archive-date=February 4, 2003}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Listen Up, Mr. President: Everything You Always Wanted Your President to Know and Do |isbn=978-1-4391-4815-0 |last=Thomas |first=Helen |author2=Craig Crawford |publisher=Scribner}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/joseph-a-palermo/meg-whitmans-vision-thing_b_300845.html |title=Joseph A. Palermo: Meg Whitman's "Vision Thing" |work=The Huffington Post |access-date=September 5, 2010 |date=September 26, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.timesargus.com/article/20090929/NEWS02/909290341/1003/NEWS02 |title=It's time to do the 'vision' thing: Times Argus Online |publisher=Timesargus.com |date=September 29, 2009 |access-date=September 5, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130204102054/http://www.timesargus.com/article/20090929/NEWS02/909290341/1003/NEWS02 |archivedate=February 4, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Mazurak |first=Zbigniew |url=http://www.therealitycheck.org/?p=7492 |title=Blog Archive » Sarah Palin as a GOP Nominee? |publisher=The Reality Check |access-date=September 5, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://rothkopf.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2009/10/01/barack_obama_does_not_want_to_become_known_as_the_great_ditherer |title=Obama does not want to become known as 'The Great Ditherer' |first=David |last=Rothkopf |date=October 1, 2009 |work=Foreign Policy |access-date=September 5, 2010}}</ref> "He does not say why he wants to be there", wrote columnist George Will, "so the public does not know why it should care if he gets his way".<ref name="senate" />
His [[Ivy League]] and prep school education led to warnings by advisors that his image was too "[[preppy]]" in 1980, which resulted in deliberate efforts in his 1988 campaign to shed the image, including meeting voters at factories and shopping malls, abandoning set speeches. Bush's campaign director [[Roger Ailes]] and others were concerned that Bush was seen as a "wimp." Bush put that image to rest when he displayed evident fury during an interview with [[Dan Rather]] on January 25, 1988.<ref name="senate" />
His ability to gain broad international support for the [[Gulf War]] and the war's result were seen as both a diplomatic and military triumph,<ref name="white house bio" /> rousing bipartisan approval,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://people-press.org/report/182/modest-bush-approval-rating-boost-at-wars-end |title=Modest Bush Approval Rating Boost at War's End: Summary of Findings – Pew Research Center for the People & the Press |publisher=People-press.org |access-date=September 5, 2010|date=April 18, 2003}}</ref> though his decision to withdraw without removing [[Saddam Hussein]] left mixed feelings, and attention returned to the domestic front and a souring economy.<ref name="pbs">{{cite web |url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/bush41/program/intro.html |work=American Experience |title=George H. W. Bush |publisher=PBS |date=October 3, 1990 |access-date=September 5, 2010}}</ref> A ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'' article mistakenly depicted Bush as being surprised to see a supermarket [[barcode reader]];<ref name=Goldberg08>{{cite journal |author=Goldberg, Jonah |date=August 22, 2008 |title=The Corner: The Supermarket Scanner Story Cont'd |journal=[[National Review]] |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/167613/supermarket-scanner-story-contd-jonah-goldberg | access-date=June 26, 2017}}</ref><ref name=Rosenthal92>{{cite news |author=Rosenthal, Andrew |date=February 5, 1992 |title=Bush Encounters the Supermarket, Amazed |journal=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/02/05/us/bush-encounters-the-supermarket-amazed.html | access-date=November 5, 2015}}</ref> the report of his reaction exacerbated the notion that he was "out of touch".<ref name=Goldberg08 /> Amid the [[early 1990s recession]], his image shifted from "conquering hero" to "politician befuddled by economic matters".<ref name=snopes />
Although Bush became the first elected Republican president since Hoover in [[1932 United States presidential election|1932]] to lose a reelection bid (facing a 34% approval rating leading up to the 1992 election), the mood did not last. Despite his defeat, Bush climbed back from election day approval levels to leave office in 1993 with a 56% job approval rating.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/sections/politics/DailyNews/poll%5Fclintonlegacy010117.html |title=Poll: Clinton Legacy Mixed |author=Langer, Gary |publisher=ABC News |date=January 17, 2001 |access-date=April 11, 2008}}</ref> By December 2008, 60% of Americans gave Bush's presidency a positive rating.<ref>{{cite news |last=Steinhauser |first=Paul |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/01/07/polls.former.presidents/index.html#cnnSTCText |title=Views soften on 2 former presidents, CNN poll finds |publisher=CNN |access-date=September 5, 2010}}</ref>
==Post-presidency (1993–2018)== ===During Clinton presidency=== Upon leaving office, Bush retired with his wife, Barbara, and temporarily moved into a friend's house near the [[Tanglewood, Houston|Tanglewood]] community of Houston as they prepared to build a permanent retirement house nearby.<ref>"[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=26kkAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fQcEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5357,12289 From White House to 'regular house']". [[Associated Press]] at the ''[[Star-Banner|Ocala Star-Banner]]''. Saturday November 21, 1992. 2A. Retrieved from [[Google Books]] (2 of 84) on October 14, 2012.</ref> Ultimately they built their retirement house in the community of [[West Oaks, Houston|West Oaks]], near Tanglewood.<ref name=Feldman /> They had a presidential office within the Park Laureate Building on [[Memorial Drive (Houston)|Memorial Drive]].<ref>"[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=ST&s_site=dfw&p_multi=ST&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAF8EDE5F8E0428&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D Bushes upbeat for step-down]". ''[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]]''. January 10, 1993. 1 News. Retrieved on October 15, 2012. "Bush's Houston office will be in the Park Laureate Building on Memorial Drive"</ref> Mimi Swartz of ''[[National Geographic]]'' wrote that "The Bushes are too studiously sedate to live in [[River Oaks, Houston|River Oaks]]".<ref name=SwartzRO>Swartz, Mimi. "[http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/ngm/0603/feature8/ Survival of the Richest]." ''[[National Geographic]]''. March 2006. Retrieved on June 4, 2014.</ref> They spent their summers at [[Bush compound|Walker's Point]] in [[Kennebunkport, Maine]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Sharp |first=David |date=May 20, 2018 |title=George H.W. Bush arrives in Kennebunkport for summer |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2018/05/20/year-old-president-bush-due-arrive-maine/vr07ZH9LrRKD3ooTsYwSsJ/story.html |work=[[The Boston Globe]] |agency=Associated Press |access-date=November 30, 2018}}</ref>
[[File:President Bill Clinton meeting with former Presidents George H.W. Bush and Jimmy Carter at the White House.jpg|thumb|President [[Bill Clinton]] meeting with former Presidents George H.W. Bush and [[Jimmy Carter]] at the White House in September 1993]]
In 1993, Bush was targeted in an assassination plot when he visited Kuwait to commemorate the coalition's victory over Iraq in the Gulf War. Kuwaiti authorities arrested 17 people who were allegedly involved in using a car bomb in an attempt to kill Bush. Through interviews with the suspects and examinations of the bomb's circuitry and wiring, the FBI established that the plot had been directed by the [[Iraqi Intelligence Service]]. A Kuwaiti court later convicted all but one of the defendants. Two months later, Clinton retaliated when he ordered the [[1993 cruise missile strikes on Iraq|firing]] of 23 [[cruise missile]]s at Iraqi Intelligence Service headquarters in [[Baghdad]]. The day before the strike, U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations [[Madeleine Albright]] went before the Security Council to present evidence of the Iraqi plot. After the missiles were fired, Vice President [[Al Gore]] said the attack "was intended to be a proportionate response at the place where this plot" to assassinate Bush "was hatched and implemented".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/longroad/etc/assassination.html |title=frontline: the long road to war: assassination |publisher=PBS |access-date=September 5, 2010}}</ref>
In September 1993, Bush and other living former presidents were invited back to the White House for an Arab-Israeli peace accord. They also made the case to Clinton for a repeal of [[North American Free Trade Agreement|NAFTA]].<ref>{{cite book |title=Destiny and Power: The American Odyssey of George Herbert Walker Bush |first=Jon |last=Meacham |page=543 |year=2015 |isbn=978-1400067657 |publisher=Random House}}</ref>
In April 1994, Bush attended the [[Death and state funeral of Richard Nixon|funeral of Richard Nixon]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/04/28/us/37th-president-overview-nixon-buried-note-praise-reconciliation.html |title=The 37th President |first=Maureen |last=Dowd |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=April 28, 1994}}</ref>
In the 1994 gubernatorial elections, his sons George W. and Jeb concurrently ran for [[Governor of Texas]] and [[List of Governors of Florida|Governor of Florida]]. The elder Bush frequently telephoned campaign headquarters for updates on the race.<ref>Meacham, p. 549.</ref> George W. won his race against [[Ann Richards]] while Jeb lost to [[Lawton Chiles]]. After the results came in, the elder Bush told ABC, "I have very mixed emotions. Proud father, is the way I would sum it all up."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/11/09/us/1994-elections-nation-bushes-texas-elects-george-w-while-florida-rejects-jeb.html |title=The 1994 Elections: The Nation The Bushes; Texas Elects George W. While Florida Rejects Jeb |date=November 9, 1994 |first=Sam Howe |last=Verhovek |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> Jeb would again run for governor of Florida in 1998 and win at the same time that his brother George W. won re-election in Texas. It marked the second time in United States history that a pair of brothers served simultaneously as governors.<ref>{{cite news |last=Rosenbaum |first=David E. |date=November 4, 1998 |title=George W. Bush Is Re-elected in Texas; His Brother Jeb Is Victorious in Florida |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/04/us/1998-elections-nation-governors-george-w-bush-re-elected-texas-his-brother-jeb.html |work=The New York Times |access-date=November 30, 2018}}</ref>
From 1993 to 1999, he served as the chairman of the board of trustees for [[Eisenhower Fellowships]],<ref>{{cite news |date=May 19, 1999 |title=For Bush, a 2-day whirlwind of awards |page= |work=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]] |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/179691578/ |via=Newspapers.com |access-date=December 1, 2018}} {{free access}}</ref> and from 2007 to 2009 was chairman of the [[National Constitution Center]].<ref>{{cite news |date=December 1, 2018 |title=Former President George H.W. Bush dies at 94 |url=https://www.ktre.com/2018/12/01/george-hw-bush-dies/ |publisher=[[KTRE]] |access-date=December 1, 2018}}</ref>
On September 28, 1994, Bush said he was opposed to sending American troops to [[Haiti]], citing his loss of confidence in [[President of Haiti]] [[Jean-Bertrand Aristide]] while speaking to business and civic leaders in [[Houston]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1994/09/28/Bush-has-lost-confidence-in-Aristide/2821780724800/ |title=Bush has lost confidence in Aristide |first=Paula |last=Dittrick |date=September 28, 1994 |publisher=UPI}}</ref>
In an October 22, 1994 speech in [[Cancún]], Mexico, Bush said history would vindicate him for not attempting to force Saddam Hussein out of power while in office: "The Mideast peace talks that offer hope to the world would never have started if we had done that. The Arabs would never have talked to us."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/10/23/world/bush-on-iraq.html |title=Bush on Iraq |date=October 23, 1994 |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref>
[[File:Unveiling of official George H. W. Bush portrait at the White House, 1995 2.jpg|thumb| The unveiling of an official portrait of George H. W. Bush at the [[East Room]] of the White House, 1995]] On July 17, 1995, Bush returned to the White House for the unveiling of his official portrait in an East Room ceremony attended by former members of his administration.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/18/us/bush-portraits-unveiled-at-white-house.html |title=Bush Portraits Unveiled at White House |date=July 18, 1995 |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref>
In September 1995, Bush met with [[President of Vietnam]] [[Lê Đức Anh]] and party secretary [[Đỗ Mười]] in Vietnam.<ref>{{cite book |last=Bush |first=Barbara |title=Reflections: Life After the White House |publisher=Scribner |year=2004 |isbn=978-0743255820 |pages=85–86}}</ref> On September 2, Bush and his son George W. participated in a parade commemorating World War II in [[Fredericksburg, Texas]], where the elder Bush reasoned the United States had become united in the aftermath of the [[attack on Pearl Harbor]] and stressed America would have to stay involved in world affairs to continue its unity.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1995/09/02/Bush-US-united-by-world-involvement/9398810014400/ |title=Bush: U.S. united by world involvement |date=September 2, 1995 |publisher=UPI}}</ref>
On July 26, 1996, Bush met with Republican presidential candidate [[Bob Dole]] and pledged he would do everything in his power to aid in securing a victory for Dole in the upcoming [[1996 United States presidential election|presidential election]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1996/07/26/Bush-vows-to-help-Dole-win-White-House/9683838353600/?spt=su |title=Bush vows to help Dole win White House |date=July 26, 1996 |publisher=UPI}}</ref> The two met again in October while Dole was preparing for upcoming debates with President Clinton. Bush's experience with debating Clinton prompting Dole to seek out his advice.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/06/us/dole-concludes-debate-preparation-by-asking-bush-for-advice.html |title=Dole Concludes Debate Preparation by Asking Bush for Advice |date=October 6, 1996 |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref>
In February 1997, Bush endorsed the chemical weapon banning treaty supported by [[United States Secretary of State]] Madeleine Albright, saying the United States would need to approve the treaty ahead of the April deadline.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/09/world/bush-backs-albright-on-chemical-arms-ban.html |title=Bush Backs Albright on Chemical Arms Ban |date=February 9, 1997 |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref>
In April 1997, Bush gave a speech at a convocation of a weekend conference analyzing his presidency<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/20/us/bush-is-a-self-effacing-figure-at-meeting-on-his-leadership.html |title=Bush Is a Self-Effacing Figure At Meeting on His Leadership |first=Clifford |last=Krauss |date=April 20, 1997 |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> and joined President [[Bill Clinton]], former President Ford, and Nancy Reagan in signing the "Summit Declaration of Commitment" in advocating for participation by private citizens in solving domestic issues within the United States.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/29/us/presidents-call-for-big-citizenship-not-big-government.html |title=Presidents Call for Big Citizenship, Not Big Government |first=James |last=Bennet |date=April 29, 1997 |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> Also in April 1997, the Houston Intercontinental Airport was renamed [[George Bush Intercontinental Airport]] after a proposal received the unanimous approval of the [[Houston City Council]].<ref>{{cite news |date=April 16, 1997 |title=Houston renaming airport after Bush |url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1997/04/16/Houston-renaming-airport-after-Bush/6521861163200/ |publisher=UPI |access-date=November 30, 2018}}</ref> The renaming took effect on May 2, with Bush presiding over the ceremonies as he took a 50-minute flight during the official changeover.<ref>{{cite news |last=Jicha |first=Tom |date=May 2, 1997 |title=Houston Airport renamed after Bush |url=https://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/fl-xpm-1997-05-02-9705010484-story.html |work=[[Sun-Sentinel|South Florida Sun-Sentinel]] |access-date=November 30, 2018}}</ref>
[[File:Inauguration ceremony of Jeb Bush.jpg|thumb|Inauguration ceremony of [[Jeb Bush]] in January 1999]] In August 1997, Bush agreed to be interviewed by ''[[The New York Times]]'', as long as he would not be portrayed as giving credit to himself over the balanced budget deal that was composed by President Clinton and House Speaker [[Newt Gingrich]]. During a telephone interview, he stated his belief that history would show that his administration laid the groundwork for the agreement.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/08/us/in-balanced-budget-deal-bush-is-off-the-seesaw.html |title=In Balanced-Budget Deal, Bush Is Off the Seesaw |first=David E. |last=Rosenbaum |date=August 8, 1997}}</ref>
President Bush was Honorary Chairman of [[Points of Light]], an international nonprofit dedicated to engaging more people and resources in solving serious social problems through voluntary service.<ref name="POL Board membership">{{cite web |title=Points of Light: Our Leadership |url=http://www.pointsoflight.org/our-leadership#bm |publisher=Points of Light |access-date=May 23, 2013}}</ref>
In January 1999, Bush spoke in the Old Senate chamber as part of a lecture series for Senators in an address warning against the collapse of political decorum and invasions into the privacy of individuals.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/01/21/us/state-union-ex-president-speech-senators-bush-laments-decline-civility-privacy.html |title=STATE OF THE UNION: THE EX-PRESIDENT; In Speech to Senators, Bush Laments Decline of Civility and Privacy |first=Frank |last=Bruni |date=January 21, 1999 |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref>
In February 1999, Bush was part of the American delegation to the funeral of [[Hussein of Jordan]] in [[Amman]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/02/09/world/death-king-americans-clinton-lauds-king-hussein-man-vision-spirit.html |title=DEATH OF A KING: THE AMERICANS; Clinton Lauds King Hussein As Man of Vision and Spirit |first=John |last=Broder |date=February 9, 1999 |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref>
In April 1999, Bush called for the release of former Chilean dictator [[Augusto Pinochet]] when [[Indictment and arrest of Augusto Pinochet|Spain had him arrested]] and sought to try him for human rights violations.<ref>{{cite web |title=Former U.S. President Bush urges Pinochet release |url=http://www.latinamericanstudies.org/chile/bush.htm |publisher=CNN |via=Reuters |date=April 12, 1999 |access-date=December 11, 2017}}</ref>
In May 1999, Bush and his wife Barbara honored six senior citizens during the annual Ageless Heroes honors in Chicago, Illinois.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.upi.com/Archives/1999/05/18/Bush-honors-senior-ageless-heroes/8710927000000/ |title=Bush honors senior 'ageless heroes' |date=May 18, 1999 |publisher=UPI}}</ref>
=== During George W. Bush presidency === [[File:G & B. Bush F-SD-03-15575.jpg|left|thumb|upright=0.9|George and Barbara Bush, 2001]] His eldest son, [[George W. Bush]], was inaugurated as the 43rd president of the United States on January 20, 2001, and re-elected in 2004. Through previous administrations, the elder Bush had ubiquitously been known as "George Bush" or "President Bush", but following his son's election the need to distinguish between them has made [[retronym]]ic forms such as "George H. W. Bush" and "George Bush senior" and colloquialisms such as "Bush 41" and "Bush the Elder" much more common. H.W. Bush was traveling to [[Minnesota]] for a speaking engagement on the day of the [[September 11 attacks]]. George W. made multiple calls to get in contact with his father before the two men reconnected after the elder Bush had gone to a [[Brookfield, Wisconsin]] motel.<ref>{{cite book |title=41: A Portrait of My Father |first=George W. |last=Bush |authorlink=George W. Bush |publisher=Crown Publishers |isbn=978-0553447781 |page=265|year=2014}}</ref> Bush told biographer [[Jon Meacham]] that his son's vice president, Dick Cheney, underwent a change following the September 11 attacks: "His seeming knuckling under to the real hard-charging guys who want to fight about everything, use force to get our way in the Middle East."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/05/us/politics/elder-bush-says-his-son-was-served-badly-by-aides.html |title=Elder Bush Says His Son Was Served Badly by Aides |date=November 4, 2015 |work=[[The New York Times]] |first=Peter |last=Baker}}</ref>
In December 2002, George W. sought counsel from the elder Bush regarding Iraq and informed him of "my efforts to rally the Saudis, Jordanians, Turks, and others in the Middle East".<ref>Meacham, pp. 571-572.</ref>
Following the fall of Baghdad, Bush praised George W. in an April 2003 email to the incumbent president.<ref>Meacham, p. 274.</ref> In a September 14, 2003 interview with BBC, Bush stated his support for a continuation of his son's war against terrorism and the US was in a better state in terms of protecting itself from terrorism than two years prior.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/2003/09/14/Ex-president-Bush-backs-war-on-terrorism/87711063557337/ |title=Ex-president Bush backs war on terrorism |date=September 14, 2003 |publisher=UPI}}</ref> While visiting Houston VA Medical Center on December 17, Bush told reporters of his satisfaction with the capture of Saddam Hussein.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/2003/12/17/Elder-Bush-says-capture-magical-moment/99301071700689/ |title=Elder Bush says capture magical moment |publisher=UPI |date=December 17, 2003}}</ref>
President and Mrs. Bush attended the [[Death and state funeral of Ronald Reagan|state funeral of Ronald Reagan]] in June 2004,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/06/12/us/the-40th-president-faces-in-the-four-thousand.html |title=The 40th President; Faces in the Four Thousand |date=June 12, 2004 |first=Brian |last=Wingfield}}</ref> and [[Death and state funeral of Gerald Ford|of Gerald Ford]] in January 2007.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/03/us/03ford.html |title=Ford Is Remembered at Funeral in Washington |first=Scott |last=Shane |date=January 3, 2007 |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> One month later, he was awarded the [[Ronald Reagan Freedom Award]] in [[Beverly Hills, California]], by former First Lady [[Nancy Reagan]]. Despite Bush's political differences with Bill Clinton, reports acknowledged that the two former presidents had become friends.<ref>{{cite news |last=Healy |first=Patrick |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/19/us/politics/19memo.html |title=A Candidacy That May Test a Friendship's Ties |work=The New York Times |date=May 19, 2007 |access-date=May 22, 2011}}</ref> He and Clinton appeared together in television ads in 2005, encouraging aid for victims of [[Hurricane Katrina]] and the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/WNT/PersonOfWeek/story?id=1446477 |title=People of the Year: Bill Clinton and George H. W. Bush |publisher=ABC News |date=December 27, 2005 |access-date=September 5, 2010}}</ref>
[[File:Vladimir Putin met with former U.S. President George Bush Sr.jpg|thumb|Bush (right) with Russian President Vladimir Putin as he receives the [[Jubilee Medal "60 Years of Victory in the Great Patriotic War 1941–1945"]] from Putin in 2005.]]
In October 2004, Bush endorsed [[Pete Sessions]] and [[Ted Poe]] in Texas congressional races.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/2004/10/27/Pa-Bush-endorses-another-Texas-candidate/13741098887403/ |title=Pa Bush endorses another Texas candidate |date=October 27, 2004 |publisher=UPI}}</ref>
In February 2006, Bush delivered a eulogy at the funeral of [[Coretta Scott King]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/2006/02/07/4-US-presidents-at-Coretta-King-funeral/36691139346252/ |title=4 U.S. presidents at Coretta King funeral |date=February 7, 2006 |publisher=UPI}}</ref>
On March 2, 2006, President Bush announced that his father would lead the American delegation to the inauguration of President-elect of the Republic of Portugal [[Aníbal Cavaco Silva]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2006/03/20060302.html |title=President Announces Former President Bush to Lead U.S. Delegation to Attend Portuguese Inauguration |website=georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov}}</ref>
In September 2006, Bush campaigned for New Jersey Senate candidate [[Thomas Kean Jr.]], praising him as well as stating his respect for Kean calling on the resignation of US Defense Secretary Rumsfeld.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/07/nyregion/07senate.html |title=Ex-Presidents, Often Allies, Divided by a Senate Race |date=September 7, 2006 |work=[[The New York Times]] |first=Richard G. |last=Jones}}</ref> Kean went on to lose the election. The following month, he was honored by the [[National Italian American Foundation]] (NIAF) with the NIAF One America Award for fundraising, with Bill Clinton, for the victims of the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami and Hurricane Katrina.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.niaf.org/news/index.asp?id=782 |title=Univision CEO Joe Uva to Receive One America Award |publisher=National Italian American Foundation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120612022655/http://niaf.org/news/index.asp?id=782 |archive-date=June 12, 2012 |access-date=July 30, 2016}}</ref>
On February 18, 2008, Bush formally endorsed Senator [[John McCain]] for President of the United States.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/02/18/AR2008021800930.html |title=George H. W. Bush Endorses McCain for President |date=February 18, 2008 |access-date=March 28, 2008 |work=The Washington Post}}</ref> The endorsement offered a boost to McCain's campaign, because the [[Arizona]] Senator had been facing criticism among many conservatives.<ref name="latimes-mccain">{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/politics/la-na-campaign19feb19,0,856707.story |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080314155546/http://www.latimes.com/news/politics/la-na-campaign19feb19%2C0%2C856707.story |archivedate=March 14, 2008 |title=Former President Bush Endorses McCain |date=February 18, 2008 |access-date=March 28, 2008 |work=Los Angeles Times |author=Neuman, Johanna |deadurl=yes |df=}}</ref> During a trip to Tokyo, Japan, Bush said that he would campaign vigorously against Senator [[Hillary Clinton]] if she were to initiate a presidential bid.<ref>{{cite web | title=Elder Bush: 'Beat the hell' out of Hillary | publisher=UPI | date=December 16, 2006 | url=https://www.upi.com/Elder-Bush-Beat-the-hell-out-of-Hillary/26041166298156/ | access-date=December 1, 2018}}</ref>
In March 2008, Bush met with [[President of the People's Republic of China]] [[Hu Jintao]], who praised Bush for his attempts at harmonizing relations between the US and China.<ref>{{cite web | title=Former U.S. president Bush visits China | publisher=UPI | date=March 8, 2008 | url=https://www.upi.com/Former-US-president-Bush-visits-China/11991205012399/ | access-date=December 1, 2018}}</ref> [[File:George H. W. Bush and George W. Bush with Hu Jintao.jpg|thumb|George H. W. Bush with son George W. Bush and China's President [[Hu Jintao]] in Beijing, People's Republic of China, August 10, 2008]]
During an address at the [[University of Kansas]] on November 16, 2008, Bush said that President-elect Obama would encounter diverse issues upon taking office and experience a wave of enthusiasm.<ref>{{cite web | title=Elder Bush says Obama will face tough job | publisher=UPI | date=November 17, 2008 | url=https://www.upi.com/Elder-Bush-says-Obama-will-face-tough-job/78081226934880/ | access-date=December 1, 2018}}</ref>
On January 10, 2009, George H. W. and George W. Bush were both present at the commissioning of {{USS|George H.W. Bush}} (CVN-77), the tenth and last {{sclass-|Nimitz|aircraft carrier|0}} [[Aircraft carrier#Supercarrier|supercarrier]] of the United States Navy.<ref Name="NavyNews12182008">{{cite web |title=Future USS George H. W. Bush to Transit |publisher=Naval Sea Systems Command Public Affairs |date=December 18, 2008 |url=http://www.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=41503 |access-date=December 22, 2008}}</ref><ref name="NewCarrier">{{cite news |url=http://hamptonroads.com/2009/01/carrier-awaits-call-come-life-ceremony-today |title=Carrier awaits a call to come to life in ceremony today |last=Jones |first=Matthew |date=January 10, 2009 |work=The Virginian Pilot |publisher=Landmark Communications |access-date=January 10, 2009}}</ref> Bush paid a visit to the carrier again on May 26, 2009.<ref>{{cite web | title=Former President Bush Visits Namesake Aircraft Carrier | publisher=United States Navy | date=May 27, 2009 | url=https://www.navy.mil/submit/display.asp?story_id=45678 | access-date=November 1, 2018}}</ref>
===During Obama presidency=== In June 2009, Bush came out in support for [[Sonia Sotomayor]] to receive fair hearings in her nomination for Associate Justice of the Supreme Court. "She was called by somebody a racist once. That's not right. I mean, that's not fair. It doesn't help the process. You're out there name-calling. So let them decide who they want to vote for and get on with it."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/2009/06/12/Bush-defends-Sotomayor-nomination/38421244850651/ |title=Bush defends Sotomayor nomination |date=June 12, 2009 |publisher=UPI}}</ref>
[[File:US Navy 090109-N-7656T-060 Capt. Kevin E. O-Flaherty-- commanding officer of the aircraft carrier USS George H.W. Bush -CVN 77- --escorts former President George H.W. Bush.jpg|thumb|left|Capt. Kevin E. O'Flaherty, commanding officer of the aircraft carrier {{USS|George H.W. Bush}}, escorts former President George H. W. Bush, 2009]] In October 2009, Bush criticized the rampant criticism of the current times, reflecting that he did not receive such "day in and day out" during his presidency and named [[Keith Olbermann]] and [[Rachel Maddow]] of [[MSNBC]] as examples; he called the two "sick puppies."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/elder-bush-decries-lack-of-civility-in-politics/ |title=Elder Bush Decries Lack of Civility in Politics |date=October 16, 2009 |publisher=CBS News}}</ref> Also during that month, on October 16, Bush joined President [[Barack Obama]] onstage at [[Texas A&M University]] for a promotion of volunteering.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/17/us/politics/17obama.html |title=Two Presidents Share a Stage on the Subject of Service |date=October 16, 2009 |first=Peter |last=Baker |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref>
Following in the footsteps of his father and grandfather, Bush was an avid golfer. In 2011, he was inducted in the [[World Golf Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldgolfhalloffame.org/george-h-w-bush/ |title=Bush, George H.W. |access-date=June 1, 2018}}</ref>
On February 15, 2011, he was awarded the [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]]—the highest civilian honor in the United States—by President [[Barack Obama]].<ref>For the transcript of Obama's remarks honoring Bush, see {{cite web |url=https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/photos-and-video/video/2011/02/15/2010-presidential-medal-freedom-ceremony |title=2010 Presidential Medal of Freedom Ceremony |publisher=The White House |date=February 15, 2011}}</ref>
On March 29, 2012, Bush endorsed [[Mitt Romney]] for the Republican presidential nomination in the 2012 Presidential election. [[NBC News]] reported that Bush had chosen to support Romney three months prior.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.upi.com/George-HW-Bush-endorses-Romney/52521333006200/ |title=George H.W. Bush endorses Romney |date=March 29, 2012 |publisher=UPI}}</ref>
In July 2013, Bush had his head shaved in a show of support for the two-year-old son of a member of his security detail, who had [[leukemia]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Edwards |first=Breanna |title=George H.W. Bush shaves head |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2013/07/george-hw-bush-shaves-head-94700.html |newspaper=Politico |date=July 24, 2013}}</ref> On July 7, Bush met with [[Gabrielle Giffords]] for part of her week-long Rights and Responsibilities Tour advocating expanded background checks in relation to firearm purchases.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2013/07/07/Giffords-meets-with-George-HW-Bush/66501373207418/ |title=Giffords meets with George H.W. Bush |publisher=UPI |date=July 7, 2013}}</ref>
[[File:Barack Obama and George H. W. Bush in the Oval Office.jpg|thumb|Bush meets President [[Barack Obama]] in the Oval Office, January 30, 2010]] In April 2014, Frederick D. McClure, chief executive of the Bush library foundation, organized a three-day gathering in [[The Woodlands, Texas|College Park, Texas]], to mark the 25th anniversary of the Bush administration. Also in early 2014, the [[John F. Kennedy]] Library Foundation presented the [[Profile in Courage Award]] to Bush and [[Mount Vernon]] awarded him its first [[Cyrus A. Ansary]] Prize.<ref name="autogenerated1">[[Peter Baker (journalist)|Baker, Peter]], [https://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/04/us/politics/hindsight-proves-kinder-and-gentler-to-bush-41.html "Bush 41 Reunion Looks to Burnish His Legacy"], ''New York Times'', April 3, 2014. Retrieved April 4, 2014.</ref> The Kennedy foundation award was presented by [[Jack Schlossberg]], the late president's grandson, to [[Lauren Bush]] Lauren, who accepted on her grandfather's behalf.<ref>Edelman, Adam, [http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/george-h-w-bush-honored-kennedy-profile-courage-award-article-1.1779221 "George H.W. Bush honored with Kennedy Profile in Courage Award"], New York ''Daily News'', May 4, 2014. Retrieved June 1, 2014.</ref> The Ansary prize was presented in Houston with Ansary, Barbara Lucas, [[Ryan Crocker|Ryan C. Crocker]], dean of the Bush school since January 2010, Barbara Bush, and Curt Viebranz in attendance with the former president. Bush directed $50,000 of the prize to the [[Bush School of Government and Public Service]] at [[Texas A&M University]], and $25,000 will fund an animation about the [[Siege of Yorktown]] for Mount Vernon.<ref>{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140602195113/http://www.mountvernon.org/ansaryprize |archivedate=June 2, 2014 |title=Former U.S. President Honored with Ansary Prize |url=http://www.mountvernon.org/ansaryprize |publisher=Mt. Vernon web page |access-date=March 18, 2016}}</ref> Viebranz and Lucas represented Mount Vernon at the presentation.<ref>[http://www.mountvernon.org/about/senior-staff Senior staff], ''mountvernon.org''. Viebranz is identified as president and CEO of George Washington's Mount Vernon. Retrieved June 14, 2014.</ref><ref>[http://www.mountvernon.org/video/watch/presidents-day-2014--barbara-lucas "Presidents Day 2014 — Barbara Lucas"], ''mountvernon.org''. Lucas is identified as regent of Mount Vernon's Ladies' Association. Retrieved June 14, 2014.</ref>
On June 12, 2014, Bush fulfilled a long-standing promise by [[Parachuting|skydiving]] on his 90th birthday. He made the parachute jump from a helicopter near his home at 11:15 a.m. in Kennebunkport, Maine. The jump marked the eighth time the former president had skydived, including jumps on his 80th and 85th birthday as well.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tmz.com/2014/06/12/george-h-w-bush-skydiving-video/ |title=George H. W. Bush SKYDIVES for His 90th Birthday! |publisher=[[TMZ]] |date=June 12, 2014 |access-date=July 2, 2014}}</ref> He had [[Twitter|tweeted]] about the incident prior to the jump, saying "It's a wonderful day in Maine — in fact, nice enough for a parachute jump."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/theoval/2014/06/12/george-hw-bush-sky-dive-nbc-today-jenna-bush-hager/10362901/ |title=George H.W. Bush takes one last skydive for 90th birthday |last=Jackson |first=David |work=[[USA Today]] |date=June 12, 2014 |access-date=July 2, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite tweet |user=GeorgeHWBush |number=477061870478581760 |date=June 12, 2018 |title=It's a wonderful day in Maine -- in fact, nice enough for a parachute jump.}}</ref>
[[File:Bushes and Pences C38RSFoVYAAZCI2.jpg|thumb|right|The Bushes with Vice President [[Mike Pence]] and family, wife [[Karen Pence|Karen]] and daughter [[Charlotte Pence|Charlotte]], 2017.]] On December 7, 2016, Bush and former Senator [[Bob Dole]] commemorated the 75th anniversary of the [[attack on Pearl Harbor]] by appearing at the Bush School of Government and Public Service at Texas A&M University.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/12/07/politics/george-hw-bush-bob-dole-pearl-harbor-anniversary/index.html |title=George H.W. Bush and Bob Dole reunite for Pearl Harbor Anniversary |publisher=CNN |first=Terence |last=Burliij |date=December 7, 2016}}</ref>
====2016 election==== In November 2014, George W. confirmed that his father wanted Jeb to launch a presidential bid in [[2016 United States presidential election|2016]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.azcentral.com/story/news/politics/2014/11/11/bush-father-son-want-jeb-bush-white-house/18873307/ |title=Bush father, son want Jeb Bush to run for White House |date=November 11, 2014 |publisher=azcentral.com}}</ref> Jeb decided to run for president, but struggled and withdrew from the Republican primary in the wave of anti-establishment sentiment led by [[Donald Trump]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2016/05/05/george-w-bush-trump-former-presidents/83962432/ |title=Bush 41, 43 won't be endorsing Trump |first=Eliza |last=Collins |publisher=USA Today}}</ref> All three Bushes emerged as frequent critics of Trump's policies and speaking style, while Trump frequently criticized George W. Bush's presidency. George H.W. Bush later said that he voted for the Democratic nominee, Hillary Clinton, in the general election instead of Trump.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2017/11/04/both-bush-presidents-openly-condemned-trump-book-claims-one-even-voted-for-clinton/ |title=White House attacks legacies of both Bush presidents after reports they refused to vote for Trump |last=Selk |first=Avi |date=November 4, 2017 |work=[The Washington Post]] |access-date=November 4, 2017}}</ref> After Trump won the election, Bush sent him a congratulatory message.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2016/live-updates/general-election/real-time-updates-on-the-2016-election-voting-and-race-results/george-h-w-bushs-message-to-donald-trump/ |title=George H. W. Bush's message to Donald Trump |work=[[The Washington Post]] |first=Lindsey |last=Bever |date=November 9, 2016}}</ref>
===During Trump presidency=== On February 5, 2017, George and Barbara Bush participated in the coin toss for [[Super Bowl LI]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.houstonchronicle.com/news/houston-texas/houston/article/Former-President-Bush-fired-up-for-coin-toss-at-10909057.php |title=Former President Bush 'fired up' for coin toss at Houston's Super Bowl |author=George, Cindy |work=[[Houston Chronicle]] |date=February 4, 2017 |access-date=February 5, 2017}}</ref>
On August 16, 2017, Bush and his son George W. released a joint statement in which they condemned the violence at the [[Unite the Right rally]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2017/08/16/george-h-w-bush-george-w-bush-we-must-reject-hatred-all-forms/572468001/ |title=George H. W. Bush, George W. Bush: We must reject 'hatred in all forms' |first=Jessica |last=Estepa |work=USA Today |date=August 16, 2017}}</ref>
On September 7, 2017, Bush partnered with former presidents Carter, Clinton, George W. Bush, and Obama to work with [[One America Appeal]] to help the victims of [[Hurricane Harvey]] and [[Hurricane Irma]] in the [[Gulf Coast of the United States|Gulf Coast]] and [[Texas]] communities.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/349993-former-presidents-add-irma-recovery-to-fundraising-appeal |title=Former presidents fundraise for Irma disaster relief |last=Shelbourne |first=Mallory |date=September 10, 2017 |work=The Hill |access-date=September 11, 2017}}</ref>
==Personal life== ===Faith=== Bush was raised in the [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal Church]], though by the end of his life his apparent religious beliefs have been considered more in line with [[Evangelicalism|Evangelical Christian]] doctrine and practices.<ref name="Post-Faith">{{cite news |last=Johnston |first=Lori |date=December 1, 2018 |title=George H.W. Bush helped lead GOP toward evangelicalism |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/religion/2018/12/01/george-hw-bush-helped-push-gop-towards-evangelicalism/?noredirect=on&utm_term=.d5944bf67c14 |work=The Washington Post |access-date=December 1, 2018}}</ref> He cited various moments in his life deepening of his faith, including his escape from Japanese forces in 1944, and the death of his three-year-old daughter Robin in 1953.<ref name=":0" /> His faith was reflected in his [[Thousand points of light|Thousand Points of Light]] speech, his support for [[School prayer|prayer in schools]], and his support for the [[Anti-abortion movements|pro-life movement]] (following his election as vice president).<ref name="Post-Faith"/><ref name=":0">{{cite web |url=https://www.christianpost.com/news/the-faith-of-george-h-w-bush-189108/ |title=The Faith of George HW Bush |author=Gary S. Smith |date=June 26, 2017 |work=[[The Christian Post]] |access-date=June 1, 2018}}</ref>
After his wife's death in April 2018, Bush released a statement through his spokesman, saying in part, "We have faith she is in heaven, and we know life will go on — as she would have it. So, cross the Bushes off your worry list."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://abc13.com/society/she-is-in-heaven---president-george-hw-bush-/3358726/ |title="How is 41?" Family offers update on President George H.W. Bush |date=April 18, 2018 |access-date=June 1, 2018}}</ref>
===Health and longevity=== In 1991, ''The New York Times'' revealed that Bush was suffering from [[Graves' disease]], a non-contagious thyroid condition that his wife Barbara also had.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Altman |first1=Lawrence |title=In Strange Twist, Bush Is Suffering From Same Gland Disease as Wife |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/10/us/in-strange-twist-bush-is-suffering-from-same-gland-disease-as-wife.html |access-date=June 5, 2018 |work=The New York Times |date=May 10, 1991}}</ref>
On February 24, 2000, Bush was standing at a reception for 90 minutes when he felt lightheaded. He was admitted to a hospital with an [[Heart arrhythmia|irregular heartbeat]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/02/25/us/the-2000-campaign-ex-president-falls-ill.html |title=THE 2000 CAMPAIGN; Ex-President Falls Ill |date=February 25, 2000 |agency=Associated Press}}</ref> When Bush was released three days later, his doctors said that he had retained the irregularity in his heartbeat.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/02/27/us/national-news-briefs-elder-bush-is-released-after-more-heart-tests.html |title=Elder Bush Is Released After More Heart Tests |date=February 24, 2000 |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> On March 11, 2007, Bush fainted on a golf course and was admitted to the [[Eisenhower Medical Center]] in [[Rancho Mirage, California]], but was released the following morning.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/2007/03/12/Presidents-father-faints-on-golf-course/41821173725180/ |title=President's father faints on golf course |date=March 12, 2007 |publisher=UPI}}</ref>
In July 2015, Bush suffered a severe neck injury. At age 91 in October that year, he was wearing a neck brace in his first public engagement since the accident when he threw the [[ceremonial first pitch]] for the [[Houston Astros]] at [[Minute Maid Park]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=McAfee |first1=Tierney |title=PHOTO: George H.W. Bush Throws Out First Pitch at Astros Playoff Game in First Public Appearance Since Neck Injury |url=http://www.people.com/article/george-bush-throws-first-pitch-houston-astros-game-neck-injury |access-date=January 31, 2016 |work=People |date=October 12, 2015}}</ref> Bush wrote a letter to president-elect [[Donald Trump]] in January 2017 to inform him that because of his poor health, he would not be able to attend [[Inauguration of Donald Trump|Trump's inauguration]] on January 20; he gave him his best wishes. On January 18, he was admitted to the intensive care unit at [[Houston Methodist Hospital]], where he was sedated for a procedure to treat an acute respiratory problem that was stemming from pneumonia.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Garcia |first1=Feliks |title=George HW Bush sends personal note to Donald Trump on why he can't attend inauguration |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/george-hw-bush-donald-trump-inauguration-letter-president-attendance-a7534221.html |access-date=January 18, 2017 |work=The Independent |date=January 18, 2017}}</ref> Three months later, he experienced a recurrence of pneumonia and was hospitalized.<ref>{{cite news |title=Former President George HW Bush hospitalised in Houston |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/04/18/former-president-george-hw-bush-hospitalised-houston/ |newspaper=The Telegraph |access-date=April 19, 2017 |language=en |date=April 19, 2017|agency=Associated Press}}</ref>
On November 25, 2017, Bush became the [[List of presidents of the United States by age|longest-lived U.S. president]] when he surpassed the 93 years and 165 days lifespan of [[Gerald Ford]], who died in 2006.<ref>{{cite news |last=Bowden |first=John |date=November 25, 2017 |title=Bush 41 becomes longest-living president in US history |url=http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/361795-bush-41-becomes-longest-living-president-in-us-history |work=The Hill |location=Washington, D.C. | access-date=November 25, 2017}}</ref> Bush became the nation's [[Living presidents of the United States|oldest living president as well as the oldest living vice president]]. He was also the first president to reach the age of 94, reaching that milestone on June 12, 2018.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://time.com/5310620/george-hw-bush-first-president-94-years-old-birthday/ |title=George H.W. Bush Becomes First U.S. President to Turn 94 Years Old |access-date=June 27, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614021607/http://time.com/5310620/george-hw-bush-first-president-94-years-old-birthday/ |archive-date=June 14, 2018 |dead-url=yes}}</ref> The [[List of vice presidents of the United States by age|longest-lived U.S. vice president]] is [[John Nance Garner]], who died on November 7, 1967, 15 days short of his 99th birthday.<ref>{{cite news |last=Lewis |first=Janna |date=January 22, 2009 |title=Texans who were presidents, vice-presidents |url=http://www.forthoodsentinel.com/leisure/texans-who-were-presidents-vice-presidents/article_6b538cd2-aa2a-53a2-bc6f-6df30cfadf71.html |work=Fort Hood Sentinel |location=Fort Hood, Texas |access-date=April 22, 2018}}</ref>
On April 22, 2018, the day after his wife's funeral, the former president was hospitalized with a blood infection.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.dallasnews.com/news/texas/2018/04/23/george-h-w-bush-admitted-houston-hospital-blood-infection |title=George H.W. Bush admitted to Houston hospital for blood infection |date=April 23, 2018 |publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/04/23/george-hw-bush-admitted-hospital-days-wifes-death/ |title=George H.W. Bush admitted to hospital days after wife's death |first=Telegraph |last=Reporters |date=April 23, 2018 |publisher= |via=www.telegraph.co.uk|newspaper=The Telegraph}}</ref> The infection led to [[sepsis]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Gangel |first=Jamie |date=April 24, 2018 |title=Former President George H.W. Bush is alert and talking, but remains in intensive care |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/04/23/politics/george-hw-bush/index.html |publisher=CNN |access-date=November 30, 2018}}</ref> One month later, he was briefly hospitalized again, after experiencing fatigue and low blood pressure.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/05/27/politics/george-hw-bush-hospital-maine/index.html |title=George H.W. Bush hospitalized |first=Maegan |last=Vazquez |publisher=CNN|date=May 27, 2018|access-date=May 27, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/ct-president-george-hw-bush-hospitalized-20180527-story,amp.html |title=Former president George H.W. Bush is hospitalized again, spokesman says |last=Phillips |first=Kristine |work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|access-date=May 27, 2018}}</ref>
===Sexual misconduct allegations=== In October 2017, during the [[Me Too movement]], actress [[Heather Lind]] accused Bush of [[groping]] her and telling an inappropriate joke. Several other women subsequently made similar allegations, including [[Christina Baker Kline]] and Roslyn Corrigan (who was 16 years old at the time of the alleged incident in 2003).<ref>{{cite web | last=Jenkins | first=Aric | title=‘I Was a Child.’ Woman Says George H.W. Bush Groped Her When She Was 16 | website=Time | date=November 13, 2017 | url=http://time.com/5019182/george-hw-bush-groping-allegation/ | access-date=December 1, 2018}}</ref> Bush apologized for these incidents through his spokesman, Jim McGrath.<ref>{{cite news |first=Tom |last=Porter |url=https://www.newsweek.com/george-hw-bush-apologizes-after-sex-assault-allegation-692368 |title=George H.W. Bush Apologizes After Actress Heather Lind Accuses Him of Sexual Assault |work=Newsweek |date=October 25, 2017 |access-date=September 14, 2018}}</ref><ref name="NPR news">{{cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/10/26/560148936/george-h-w-bush-acknowledges-groping-multiple-women |title=George H.W. Bush Responds to Groping Allegations |work=NPR |date=October 26, 2017 |access-date=October 29, 2017 |first=James |last=Doubek}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-41987895 | title=George Bush Snr accused by interpreter| publisher=BBC News| date=November 17, 2017| last1=Bell| first1=Chris}}</ref> At the time, an editorial writer for the Washington Post noted that some would relate his behavior to his vascular parkinsonism or other senility related conditions.<ref>Molly Roberts, October 26, 2017, Washington Post, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-partisan/wp/2017/10/26/the-biggest-question-about-george-h-w-bushs-groping-scandal/?utm_term=.7ad42ce59a56 The biggest question about the George H.W. Bush groping debacle]. Accessed December 2nd, 2018</ref> Symptoms for vascular parkinsonism may include a lack of impulse control and cognitive impairment.<ref>[http://www.mdsabstracts.com/abstract.asp?MeetingID=801&id=111258 MDS 18th International Congress of Parkinson's Disease and Movement Disorders, Volume 29, June 2014 Abstract Supplement]</ref><ref>Julie Edgar, Dec. 1, 2018: [https://www.webmd.com/stroke/news/20181201/former-president-george-hw-bush-dies Former President George H.W. Bush Dies]. WebMD</ref> The only medication available to treat vascular parkinsonism is also associated with a lack of impulse control, although it is unclear if he was receiving it or not.<ref>[https://www.apdaparkinson.org/what-is-parkinsons/symptoms/impulse-control-disorders/ Impulse Control Disorders] from apdaparkinson.org</ref>
==Death== {{main|Death and state funeral of George H. W. Bush}}
Bush suffered from vascular [[parkinsonism]], a form of [[Parkinson's disease]] that had forced him to use a motorized scooter or wheelchair since at least 2012.<ref>{{cite web |title=Photo P012712PS-0676 |url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/whitehouse/6773105167/in/photostream/ |date=January 27, 2012 |publisher=The Whitehouse |access-date=April 24, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Updegrove |first1=Mark K. |title=An Exclusive Conversation with President and Mrs. Bush |url=https://parade.com/123684/markupdegrove/15-george-hw-bush-family-is-what-matters/ |access-date=February 15, 2017 |work=[[Parade (magazine)|Parade]] |date=July 15, 2012}}</ref> He died on November 30, 2018, aged 94,<ref>{{cite news |title=Former President George H.W. Bush dead at 94 |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/president-george-hw-bush-dead-94/story?id=44866630 |publisher=ABC News |date=December 1, 2018 |access-date=December 1, 2018}}</ref> at his home in Houston.<ref name="nytimes_obituary">{{cite news |last=Nagourney |first=Adam |date=November 30, 2018 |title=George Bush, 41st President, Dies at 94 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/30/us/politics/george-hw-bush-dies.html?smid=tw-nytimes |work=The New York Times |access-date=November 30, 2018}}</ref> Tributes and condolences were offered by former Presidents [[Jimmy Carter]], [[Bill Clinton]], [[George W. Bush]], and [[Barack Obama]], and incumbent President [[Donald Trump]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/12/01/george-hw-bush-death-tributes-from-the-obamas-clintons-and-trumps.html |title=Tributes pour in for former president George HW Bush as state funeral preparations begin |first=Javier E. |last=David |first2=Kevin |last2=Breuninger |date=1 December 2018 |access-date=2 December 2018 |work=[[CNBC]] |publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/2018/12/01/672516694/presidents-react-to-george-h-w-s-bush-s-death?t=1543709980725 |title=Presidents And Former Colleagues React To George H.W. Bush's Death |first=Sasha |last=Ingber |date=1 December 2018 |access-date=2 December 2018 |work=[[NPR]]}}</ref> He will [[Lying in state|lie in state]] in the [[United States Capitol rotunda]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.foxnews.com/politics/bush-expected-to-lie-in-state-in-us-capitol-in-line-with-tradition-trump-to-attend-funeral|title=George H.W. Bush to lie in state in US Capitol; Trump to attend funeral|last=Pergram|first=Chad|date=2018-12-01|work=Fox News|access-date=2018-12-02|language=en-US}}</ref>
===Legacy=== According to ''USA Today'', the legacy of Bush's presidency was defined by his victory over Iraq after the invasion of Kuwait, and for his presiding over the collapse of the USSR and unification of Germany. The paper said his political legacy would "continue years later through his son, George W. Bush, who became the 43rd president of the United States."<ref>{{cite news|title=Remembering Former President George H.W. Bush's life and legacy |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2018/12/01/live-former-president-george-h-w-bushs-life-and-legacy/2173047002/ |newspaper=USA Today|date=December 1, 2018 |access-date=December 1, 2018}}</ref> Matt Picht from Newsy said that in Bush's legacy, he is remembered as a Foreign Policy President, for presiding over the collapse of the USSR, post Cold War relations with Russia, and for signing the START 1 treaty on nuclear weaponry. Picht wrote that his decision to arrest and depose Panama Dictator [[Manuel Noriega]] was popular at the time, but will be less fondly remembered.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Picht |first1=Matt |title=George H.W. Bush Defined Post-Soviet US Foreign Policy |url=https://www.newsy.com/stories/gulf-war-panama-define-president-george-h-w-bush-s-legacy/ |publisher=Newsy|date=November 30, 2018 |access-date=December 1, 2018}}</ref>
According to presidential historian [[Mark K. Updegrove]], Bush "cemented" the tradition of presidents writing leaving behind letters of support for their successors on the [[Resolute desk|Resolute Desk]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/12/01/us/politics/president-bush-clinton-letters.html|title=Bush’s Letter to Clinton Cemented a Presidential Tradition, Historians Say|last=Jacobs|first=Julia|date=December 1, 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=December 2, 2018|language=en}}</ref> While Reagan had been the first modern president to do so in 1989, Bush's move was significant in that his gesture of goodwill was made towards Clinton, the man to whom Bush had just lost the election.<ref name=":2" />
==Presidential library== {{Main|George Bush Presidential Library}} [[File:George Bush Presidential Library.jpg|thumb|The [[George Bush Presidential Library]] on the west campus of Texas A&M University in College Station, Texas]]
The George Bush Presidential Library is the nation's tenth [[presidential library]] and was built between 1995 and 1997.<ref>{{cite press release |date=November 6, 1997 |title=National Archives Accepts Bush Library as Tenth Presidential Library |url=https://www.archives.gov/press/press-releases/1998-47 |publisher=[[National Archives and Records Administration]] |access-date=November 30, 2018}}</ref> It contains the presidential and vice presidential papers of Bush and the vice presidential papers of [[Dan Quayle]].<ref name="bushmaterials">{{cite web |title=The Birth of the Tenth Presidential Library: The Bush Presidential Materials Project, 1993–1994 |publisher=George Bush Presidential Library |url=http://bushlibrary.tamu.edu/giq.html |access-date=March 22, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070410185146/http://bushlibrary.tamu.edu/giq.html |archivedate=April 10, 2007}}</ref> It was dedicated on November 6, 1997, and opened to the public shortly thereafter; the architectural firm of [[HOK (firm)|Hellmuth, Obata and Kassabaum]] designed the complex.<ref>{{cite news |date=November 6, 1997 |title=Bush hopes library makes history clear |url=http://www.cnn.com/US/9711/06/bush.library/index1.html?iref=newssearch |publisher=CNN |access-date=November 30, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Robbins |first=Jefferson |date=February 7, 1999 |title=Free Hand |url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-1999-02-07-9902060022-story.html |work=Chicago Tribune |access-date=November 30, 2018}}</ref>
The George Bush Presidential Library and Museum is located on a {{convert|90|acre|adj=on}} site on the west campus of [[Texas A&M University]] in [[College Station, Texas]], on a plaza adjoining the Presidential Conference Center and the Texas A&M Academic Center.<ref name="Eagle">{{cite news |last=Heathman |first=Claire |date=July 3, 2013 |title=How Texas A&M became home to the George Bush Presidential Library and Museum |url=https://www.myaggienation.com/campus_evolution/how-texas-a-m-became-home-to-the-george-bush/article_baa24bb4-e411-11e2-8085-0019bb2963f4.html |work=[[The Bryan-College Station Eagle]] |access-date=November 30, 2018}}</ref> The Library operates under [[National Archives and Records Administration|NARA]]'s administration and the provisions of the Presidential Libraries Act of 1955.<ref>{{cite news |year=2005 |title=The Presidential Libraries Act after 50 Years |url=https://www.archives.gov/publications/prologue/2005/summer/preslib.html |work=Prologue Magazine |publisher=National Archives and Records Administration |access-date=November 30, 2018}}</ref>
The [[Bush School of Government and Public Service]] is a graduate [[public policy school]] at Texas A&M University in College Station, Texas, that was established in 1995.<ref name="Eagle" /> The graduate school is part of the presidential library complex, and offers four programs — two master's degree programs (Public Service and Administration, and International Affairs) and three certificate programs (Advanced International Affairs, Nonprofit Management, and [[Homeland security|Homeland Security]]).<ref>{{cite news |last=Lyons |first=Kelan |date=October 19, 2017 |title=For alumni, the Bush School of Government & Public Service served as 'a foundation' for education |url=https://www.theeagle.com/news/local/for-alumni-the-bush-school-of-government-public-service-served/article_df3f93b1-fad3-58c5-945f-80bd2c08c4a7.html |work=The Bryan-College Station Eagle |access-date=November 30, 2018}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Use Irish English|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox tennis biography | name = Guy Jackson | nickname = | image = | caption = | country = {{flagicon|IRE}} [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1921|9|20}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|1972|6|18|1921|9|20}} | death_place = near [[Staines]],
[[England]], [[United Kingdom]] | plays = | Wimbledonresult = 2R ([[1948 Wimbledon Championships – Men's Singles|1948]], [[1949 Wimbledon Championships – Men's Singles|1949]], [[1952 Wimbledon Championships – Men's Singles|1952]]) }} '''Guy Jackson''' (20 September 1921 – 18 June 1972) was a [[tennis]] player and businessman from [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]].[http://www.itftennis.com/procircuit/players/player/profile.aspx?playerid=10003700 ITF Pro Circuit Profile] ==Career== Jackson competed at the [[Wimbledon Championships]] on eight occasions, in 1947, 1948, 1949, 1951, 1952, 1953, 1954 and 1960. He made the second round three times.[http://www.tennisarchives.com/coureurfiche.php?coureurid=3557 Tennis Archive Profile] In the [[Davis Cup]], Jackson took part in 15 ties, the first in 1948 and last in 1964.[http://www.daviscup.com/en/players/player/profile.aspx?playerid=10003700 Davis Cup Profile] He won nine singles rubbers and four doubles matches for Ireland. ==Staines air disaster== Jackson, an executive with [[Guinness Brewery]], was one of 12 Irish senior businessmen on board [[British European Airways Flight 548]], which crashed near the town of [[Staines]]. There were no survivors.''[[North Adams Transcript]]'', [https://newspaperarchive.com/north-adams-transcript/1972-06-19/ "34 Americans are among 118 dead in plane crash"], Pg. 1 ==References== {{reflist|1}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jackson, Guy}} [[Category:1921 births]] [[Category:1972 deaths]] [[Category:Victims of aviation accidents or incidents in England]] [[Category:Irish businesspeople]] [[Category:Irish male tennis players]]

Bonciu, poet - prozator.JPG | imagesize = 220px | caption = Photograph of Bonciu, dated before 1935 | pseudonym = Bon-Tsu-Haș, Sigismund Absurdul | birth_date = May 19, 1893 | birth_place = [[Iași]] | death_date = {{death date and age|mf=yes|1950|4|27|1893|5|19}} | death_place = [[Bucharest]] | occupation = poet, novelist, translator, columnist, businessman, winemaker | nationality = Romanian | period = ca. 1912–1945 | genre = ''[[Bildungsroman]]'', [[erotic literature]], [[fantasy literature]], [[Parody|lampoon]], [[lyric poetry]], [[prose poetry]], [[sonnet]] | subject = | movement = [[Avant-garde]]
