{{Other people|Joseph Martin}} {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2011}} [[File:JosephMartin.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Brigadier General, Joseph Martin Jr. (1740–1808), born [[Caroline County, Virginia]], died [[Henry County, Virginia]].]] '''Joseph Martin, Jr.''' (1740–1808) was a [[brigadier general]] in the [[Virginia militia]] during the [[American Revolutionary War]], in which Martin's frontier diplomacy with the [[Cherokee|Cherokee people]] is credited with not only averting Indian attacks on the [[Scotch-Irish American]] and [[English American]] settlers who helped win the battles of [[Battle of Kings Mountain|Kings Mountain]] and [[Battle of Cowpens|Cowpens]], but with also helping to keep the Indians' position neutral and from siding with the British troops during those crucial battles. Historians agree that the settlers' success at these two battles signaled the turning of the tide of the Revolutionary War—in favor of the Americans.
Martin was born in [[Caroline County, Virginia]], and later lived at Albemarle County and then at Henry County, Virginia, at his plantation, ''Belmont'', on [[Leatherwood Creek (Virginia)|Leatherwood Creek]] in Martinsville, not far from the plantation of his friend [[Governor of Virginia|Governor]] [[Patrick Henry]], ''[[Leatherwood Plantation]]''.
General Martin held many positions during his public life. As a very young man he first tried his hand at farming, next he worked for three years as an overseer on the huge plantation of his local Virginia kin, next he was a [[longhunter]], and an explorer on the frontier for friend Patrick Henry, then an early pioneer and builder of [[Martin's Station]] in the "wild west," a surveyor of the KY/NC and TN/VA borders, an Indian agent/Indian fighter for Patrick Henry, a member at peace treaties with the Indians, and along with Dr. Thomas Walker, Joseph Martin named the Cumberland region and the [[Cumberland River]], he served as a member of the legislatures of Virginia, Georgia, and North Carolina, he was lifelong friends with Gen. Thomas Sumter, he was also friends and brothers-in-law with Col. Benjamin Cleveland (both married Graves sisters), he was unsuccessfully nominated by Patrick Henry to the position of the first governor of the Southwest Territory, was the holder of some 80,000 acres across the Southeastern U.S. at one point. The city of [[Martinsville, Virginia]], was named in his honor during his lifetime.
==Early life== [[File:Martinsville Virginia historic marker.JPG|thumb|left|200px|Historic marker for [[Martinsville, Virginia]], named for Joseph Martin]] The son of planter Capt. Joseph Martin Sr. and his wife Susannah Chiles,<ref name = Biog>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UCgSAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA208&dq=%22general+joseph+martin%22&lr=&ei=Zwh6SYC8OpH6lQT_89C_Bg |title=Encyclopedia of Virginia Biography, Vol. I, Lyon Gardiner Tyler (ed.), Lewis Historical Publishing Company, New York, 1915 |publisher=Google Books |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref> great-granddaughter of [[Colonel]] [[John Page (Middle Plantation)|John Page]], Joseph Martin Jr. was raised in a Virginia gentry family in Caroline and Albemarle Counties.<ref name = Biog/> His father, Joseph Martin Sr., was the son of wealthy British merchant William Martin in [[Bristol]], England,<ref>The Martin family of Virginia claims descent from the Martins of Withy Bush House, Prendergast, Pembrokeshire, Wales.[https://books.google.com/books?id=f8kWVOafFtQC&pg=PA126&lpg=PA126&dq=%22sparks+martin%22+pembrokeshire&source=bl&ots=LX3BsgWrtG&sig=U_epzAKeOKSU3M34cd0lAHK04Zg&hl=en&ei=rDe8S7P1OJO2sgPckdCFBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CBgQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q&f=false]</ref> who sent his son to Virginia as [[supercargo]] aboard his ship the ''Brice''.<ref>The family name was pronounced MAR-TEEN in England, but the family's origins are likely [[Cambro-Norman]].[https://books.google.com/books?id=q748AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA409&dq=%22joseph+martin%22+%22kings+mountain%22&lr=&ei=mkl6SZmjKoWekwTLxeyMAw#PPA409,M1][https://books.google.com/books?id=g9PTESIlqwoC&pg=PA337&lpg=PA337&dq=%22rock+house%22+martin+stokes&source=bl&ots=QfLQg878SJ&sig=h-jFEnZvNXWF0dgWNA1FC7ZA7UA&hl=en&ei=0fW_S5S9OsXvngen9ZiVCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CCAQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=%22rock%20house%22%20martin%20stokes&f=false]</ref> Martin Sr. wrote to his English father that he planned to marry the daughter of a common Virginia colonist. Even though she was from the Chiles family and was a descendant of Virginia's Col. John Page, to Martin's wealthy father back in England all American colonists were inferior to the English. William Martin of Bristol was himself Lord Mayor of Bristol<ref>{{cite web |author=Document file:  Mayors of Bristol since 1216.pdf |url=http://www.bristol.gov.uk/ccm/content/Council-Democracy/Democracy-Elections/mayors-of-bristol-since-1216.en?page=6 |title=Mayors of Bristol since 1216, Bristol City Council |publisher=Bristol.gov.uk |date=June 29, 2011 |accessdate=November 28, 2011 }}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and owner of a ship building company, a glass manufacturing plant, importer and exporter with the new world; including tobacco. The father wrote back disinheriting young Joseph Martin Sr., who never returned to England.<ref name = Annual>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q748AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA409&dq=%22joseph+martin%22+%22kings+mountain%22&lr=&ei=mkl6SZmjKoWekwTLxeyMAw#PPA409,M1 |title=Annual Report of the American Historical Association for the Year 1893, Government Printing Office, Washington, D.C., 1894 |publisher=Google Books |date=August 16, 2007 |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref>
Joseph Martin Sr. was "a perfect Englishman", recalled his grandson later, "large and athletic; bold, daring, self-willed and [[Hubris|supercilious]]. And in him was depicted, as my father has told me, the most complete form of the aristocracy of the British government."<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ItIRAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA347&lpg=PA347&dq=%22brice+martin%22+%22joseph+martin%22&source=web&ots=jrmku3nLDA&sig=PluFiq0NsVdDfOXwrNMwP1auHhE&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=7&ct=result#PPA349,M1 |title=Biographical Sketch of General Joseph Martin, By His Son, Virginia Magazine of History and Biography, Virginia Historical Society, Richmond, Va., 1903 |publisher=Google Books |date=May 1, 2009 |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref> Capt. Martin arrived in Albemarle County in 1745, one of the original patentees.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XzMTAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA263&lpg=PA263&dq=hammack+%22albemarle+county%22+virginia&source=bl&ots=aDBR9jZ4U_&sig=7O4vPbdF4hjitY02eHtxuniUurQ&hl=en&ei=GJhZTILUJ4y6sQOrocm8CA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CDEQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Albemarle County in Virginia: Giving Some Account of What It Was by Nature, Edgar Woods, The Michie Company, Charlottesville, Va., 1901 |publisher=Google Books |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref> Joseph Martin Sr. left some 300 acres of his landholdings to son Joseph Jr. at his death in 1762. Nearby neighbors [[Thomas Walker (explorer)|Dr. Thomas Walker]], [[Peter Jefferson]], [[James Madison]], and the [[Lewis and Clark]] clans and kin including Lewis, Carr, Waller, Dabney, Hammock, Hughes, etc.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.danielboonetrail.com/historicalsites.php?id=89 |title=General Joseph Martin, Lawrence J. Fleenor, Jr., Daniel Boone Wilderness Trail |publisher=Danielboonetrail.com |date=June 1, 1980 |accessdate=November 28, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100920133053/http://danielboonetrail.com/historicalsites.php?id=89 |archivedate=September 20, 2010 |df= }}</ref>
But Joseph Martin Jr., the son of the English immigrant, was not cut out for a Virginia gentry planter's life. "Gambling was a favorite pastime." Martin's son, Revolutionary War officer Col. William Martin, in his accounts of his father's life in the, "[[Lyman Draper]] Manuscript Collection," writes that although his father gambled, he was not much of a drinker and let his son in on his secret; Martin sometimes pretended to over-drink so he might appear to be drunk in order that fellow gamblers would let down their guard. As a youth, Joseph Martin ran off from an apprenticeship during the [[French and Indian War]] of 1756, and joined the army at [[Fort Pitt (Pennsylvania)|Fort Pitt]], where he served alongside another Virginia youth, [[Thomas Sumter]].<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RvIOAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA164&dq=%22general+joseph+martin%22&lr=&ei=-Cd6Sf60DpeMlQTVoNm-Bg#PPA164,M1 |title=The Magazine of History with Notes and Queries, Vol. VIII, William Abbatt (ed.), New York, 1908 |publisher=Google Books |date=October 10, 2007 |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref> Following his early army service, Martin lit out for the rigors of the frontier, where he dressed in buckskin and was an early real estate speculator, trapper and fur trader and Indian fighter.<ref>Although Joseph Martin inherited from his father over 300 acres of land as well as a half-interest in a plantation on a tributary of the [[Potomac River]] that Joseph Martin Sr. held jointly with Col. Francis Warner of [[Essex County, Virginia|Essex County]], the son elected to dress in buckskin and spend his time inland on the frontier.[http://listsearches.rootsweb.com/th/read/MARTIN/2000-11/0975121791]</ref> But this time on the frontier was after Martin had bought a large plot of land in Henry County with his earnings working for three years as an overseer for an uncle. Martin also gained 20,000 acres of land from Patrick Henry in a surveying contest at Powell Valley. Martin's youthful adventures on the frontier were grist for later stories... some of which were written by Martin's political foes and were slanted to paint a picture of him in an unkind light. One writer, a fan of Martin's political enemy, called him lazy and refused to describe him by his military ranking. General Joseph Martin may have been many things in his lifetime, but a quick study of his history and his accomplishments show that he was far from lazy. Eventually the soldiering, trapping and Indian fighting transformed the young Martin into a fearsome explorer.
Among Martin's earliest excursions on the frontier was one made on behalf of family friend Dr. Thomas Walker. Martin's son, Revolutionary War officer Col. William Martin, describes the naming of the area and the river in a letter to historian [[Lyman Draper]], "A treaty with the Cherokees was held at [[Fort Chiswell, Virginia]] on New River, then a frontier. On the return of the chiefs home, Dr.[Thomas] Walker, a gentleman of distinction, and my father, [General] Joseph Martin, accompanied them. The Indians being guides, they passed through the place now called Cumberland Gap, where they discovered a fine spring. They still had a little rum remaining, and they drank to the health of the Duke of Cumberland. This gave rise to the name of Cumberland Mountain and Cumberland River."{{citation needed|date=October 2014}}
In 1769, Martin journeyed to [[Powell River (Tennessee River)|Powell's Valley]] to attempt a settlement, a full {{convert|100|mi|km}} ahead of any previous settlement.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6npr_LGJH-cC&pg=PA274&lpg=PA274&dq=%22col.+william+martin%22+tennessee&source=bl&ots=J6eMitmFIN&sig=o0u3xyXnr4Iw5hUIJeb_vbVVOxc&hl=en&ei=aYC5ScO6FJX2MJrf_J4I&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=9&ct=result#PPA75,M1 |title=The Life of Daniel Boone, Lyman Copeland Draper, Ted Franklin Belue, Stackpole Books, 1998, ISBN 0-8117-0979-5 |publisher=Google Books |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref> Martin and his party – which included his brother Brice and Mordecai Hord<ref>Born in [[Caroline County, Virginia]], Mordecai Hord was also an early settler of Henry County, where he settled on his plantation named ''Hordsville''. Hord owned 'vast tracts of land' in Powell's Valley, which he explored along with Joseph Martin.[https://books.google.com/books?id=VztVAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA21&lpg=PA21&dq=%22mordecai+hord%22+virginia&source=bl&ots=2nRc1UspmG&sig=Ggmv26zmwxxeVgjtc0NDsUt11HE&hl=en&ei=J6q5Sda4H5GYsAPlgPE-&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=5&ct=result#PPA15,M1] The two shared many of the same friends, including Patrick Henry, an executor of Hord's will along with Hord's brother-in-law Col. George Waller, married to Henry's first cousin Ann Winston (Carr) Waller.[https://books.google.com/books?id=RfocAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA74&lpg=PA74&dq=%22mordecai+hord%22&source=bl&ots=sDGcobiWpE&sig=ZB9Xn-ivUWi6PBDV8Y4VHe1aApw&hl=en&ei=x6W5Sa6pLpGUsAPn4eUy&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=4&ct=result#PPA73,M1]</ref> – had hoped to secure the {{convert|21000|acre|km2}} granted to Dr. Walker and themselves. Martin's Creek in the region where Joseph Martin attempted his settlement is today named for him. (Martin's Station, as the settlement was known, became a well-known stopover for westward-bound settlers for many years.<ref>[http://www.martinsstation.com/history.shtml A Short History of Martin's Station, Wilderness Road State Park, martinsstation.com] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080705041359/http://www.martinsstation.com/history.shtml |date=July 5, 2008 }}</ref>) The settlement ultimately failed, which some historians have blamed on the inability of the [[Ohio Company|Loyal Company]] to defend its title to the tract.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6npr_LGJH-cC&pg=PA274&lpg=PA274&dq=%22col.+william+martin%22+tennessee&source=bl&ots=J6eMitmFIN&sig=o0u3xyXnr4Iw5hUIJeb_vbVVOxc&hl=en&ei=aYC5ScO6FJX2MJrf_J4I&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=9&ct=result#PPA96,M1 |title=The Life of Daniel Boone, Lyman Copeland Draper, Ted Franklin Belue, Stackpole Books, 1998, ISBN 0-8117-0979-5 |publisher=Google Books |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref><ref>Other historians have attributed the failure of the early settlement to the resistance of the Cherokee tribe to this earliest incursion.[https://books.google.com/books?id=RaQuAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA27&dq=%27DANIEL+BOONE%22+%22JOSEPH+MA]</ref>
But in the foray to Powell's Valley, Martin had established his credentials as a hard-bitten explorer. [[Daniel Boone]] and his party of explorers were stunned in 1769 when, upon their arrival in Powell's Valley, they discovered that Martin and his 20-man party had beaten them there. It was beyond the farthest reaches that Boone and his [[long hunter]]s had explored.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4ZVFS2-dNa4C&pg=PA55&lpg=PA55&dq='DANIEL+BOONE%22+%22JOSEPH+MARTIN'&source=bl&ots=w_Uxu-Q6b0&sig=Ckx-q430m8Hoaeginc7awUgylT0&hl=en&ei=nw-7SYTeMpC6M579gbYI&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=3&ct=result |title=In the Footsteps of Daniel Boone, K. Randell Jones, Published by John F. Blair, 2005, ISBN 0-89587-308-7 |publisher=Google Books |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref> Following Martin's feat, the Albemarle County native became a force to be reckoned with in exploration circles, even though Martin's settlement was soon broken up by the Cherokees, who pushed back against the westernmost settlement yet attempted.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=W7Zy69f8sVQC&pg=PA77&lpg=PA77&dq='DANIEL+BOONE%22+%22JOSEPH+MARTIN'&source=bl&ots=nJBlYrRUu7&sig=T70VzVHNEBXPrpQeUB7cJ_tsqq0&hl=en&ei=hxS7SeuFDonwMo7jwZsI&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=4&ct=result |title=Daniel Boone: The Life and Legend of an American Pioneer, John Mack Faragher, Published by Macmillan, 1993, ISBN 0-8050-3007-7 |publisher=Google Books |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref>
By 1775, when North Carolina merchant [[Richard Henderson (American pioneer)|Richard Henderson]] purchased an immense tract of land from the Cherokees to found the short-lived [[Transylvania (colony)|Transylvania colony]], in what is today [[Kentucky]], Henderson turned to Martin as his agent in Powell's Valley.<ref>In exchange for acting as agent for the Transylvania colony, Martin was granted by founder Henderson preferential rights to Martin's land claim in Powell Valley.[https://books.google.com/books?id=8eFSK4o--M0C&pg=PA612&dq=%22thomas+walker%22+%22joseph+martin%22&lr=&ei=gZ29SZT4HpLakATw_uCDAw]</ref> It was one of several such roles that the explorer, accustomed to trapping, [[Longhunter|longhunting]] and traveling in the Appalachian wilderness inhabited by the [[Cherokee]], would hold over the years.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VPAI3Tegbl0C&pg=PA17&dq=%22thomas+walker%22+%22joseph+martin%22&ei=rYm9SamdO5vgkAT6-6TSCw |title=Historic Sullivan: a history of Sullivan County, Tennessee, with brief biographies of the makers of history, By Oliver Taylor, Published by The Overmountain Press, 1988, ISBN 0-932807-33-X |publisher=Google Books |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref><ref>An experienced longhunter and Indian trader, Martin continued to traffic in skins as late as 1781, when two Native Americans attempting to deliver skins to Martin at his Long Island settlement were slain by colonists.[https://books.google.com/books?id=-uB4AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA365&lpg=PA365&dq=%22martin's+station%22+virginia&source=bl&ots=NFh8exuTdL&sig=dluFc2CtfBQ4fexH4ES6m3Tm0v4&hl=en&ei=pnfVSo-1CY_kswPXxYHpAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CBkQ6AEwBDgK#v=onepage&q=%22martin's%20station%22%20virginia&f=false]</ref>
==[[Martin's Station]]== [[File:Joseph Martin memorial.jpg|thumb|right|300px|General Joseph Martin, Jr. (1740–1808), born [[Caroline County, Virginia]], died [[Henry County, Virginia]]. Memorial to General Joseph Martin and settlers at Martin's Station, Virginia. Photograph courtesy of dmott9.]] Martin's Station stood along the Wilderness Trail near [[Rose Hill, Lee County, Virginia|Rose Hill, Virginia]]. The first fort was built in 1769, but Martin's party were attacked by the local Native Americans. He returned a few years later in 1775 and built a new "Martin's station". Again he was attacked by the Indians and had to leave. Moving closer to the [[Cumberland Gap]], he built another new "Martin's Station", his third, in 1783. The small fort provided protection plus supplies for hunters and immigrant families moving into Kentucky. He was able to finally sell his fort and lands in [[Powell County, Kentucky]] in 1788, and moved back to the town in [[Henry County, Virginia]], that would soon be re-named in his honor: Martinsville.
A "fourth" Martin's station was recently constructed at the [[Wilderness Road State Park]]. "Builders of the hand hewn log replica, constructed in 2002, used only the kinds of tools that Martin would have used in the wild frontier in the later 1700s. Workers carted logs into the construction site with oxen and then used ropes and horses to set those logs in place. At times, [[Historical reenactment|reenactors]] came on the scene and made the construction yet authentic by staging spontaneous Indian attacks."<ref>Tennis, Joe. [http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/918591248 Along Virginia's Route 58: True Tales from Beach to Bluegrass]. 2015. Pages 237-238.</ref>
==Life along the frontier== [[File:J L Robertson General Joseph Martin 1788.jpg|thumb|right|175px|Letter from [[James Robertson (explorer)|James Robertson]], founder of [[Nashville, Tennessee]], to Joseph Martin, Jr., 1788]] "Martin was a robust figure in the history of the early frontier," according to the [[Works Progress Administration|WPA]] guide to the Old Dominion. "He was born in Albemarle County in 1740, ran away to fight Indians at 17, became an Indian agent, land agent, and officer of militia, fighting Indians all up and down the frontier. In 1774 he came to Henry County, established himself at Belle Monte on Leatherwood Creek, for nine years sat for his district in the general assembly, and in 1793 was made a brigadier general of state militia. He was a brawny, picturesque man, more than six feet tall and the father of 18 children; wore buckled knee breeches and a great beard, braided and thrust inside his shirt."<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=z2VzSg9hfp0C&pg=PA611&dq=%22general+joseph+martin%22&lr=&ei=SCt6SZPaNpOmkQTouqTUBg |title=''Virginia: A Guide to the Old Dominion'', Virginia Writers' Project, Federal Writers' Project, Oxford University Press, New York, 1956 |publisher=Google Books |date=January 1, 1972 |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref>
Martin first married Sarah Lucas in [[Orange County, Virginia]].<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hBwLAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA4&lpg=PA4&dq=%22sarah+lucas%22+%22orange+county%22+virginia&source=web&ots=FY9TCgYTYZ&sig=AZUvUyGa8SF_p01sKHucaCz90Mc&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=8&ct=result#PPA4,M1 |title=Major John Redd's Sketch of General Joseph Martin, Publications of the Southern History Association, Southern History Association, Washington, D.C., 1903 |publisher=Google Books |date=May 16, 2006 |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref> After her death in Henry County, Martin married Susannah Graves, a descendant of [[Captain Thomas Graves]]. Susannah Graves, of Spotsylvania County, Virginia, the wife of Joseph Martin, and her second cousin Mary Graves, who was married to [[Benjamin Cleveland]], Susannah Graves was the daughter of William Graves and Mary unk, Mary was the daughter of Joseph Graves and Sarah Bunyard. Both are direct descendants of Thomas Graves and Anna Davenport, common ancestor, is Capt. Thomas Graves. [Ref; Wills of Joseph Graves and Thomas Graves]. While married to Sarah Lucas and then to Susannah Graves, Martin was simultaneously married to his half-[[Cherokee]] wife, Elizabeth Ward, the daughter of [[Nancy Ward]], a power within the Cherokee tribes, and her husband, English trapper Bryan Ward.<ref name="ency">{{cite web | last = Smith| first = David Ray| title = Nancy Ward (1738–1822) Last Beloved Woman of the Cherokee | work = The Tennessee Encyclopedia of History and Culture | year = 1998 | url = http://smithdray.tripod.com/nancyward-index-5.html#nwi | accessdate = 2010-10-20 }}</ref> The polygamous relationship, justified by Martin as common practice among frontiersmen operating among the tribes, caused considerable consternation to General Martin's son, Col. William Martin.<ref>But despite his misgivings over his father's polygamous relationship, Col. William Martin was still moved to say that Betsy's Ward's mother [[Nancy Ward]] was "one of the most superior women I ever saw." [https://books.google.com/books?id=jMU0U3KqzQQC&pg=PA6&dq=%22william+martin%22+%22joseph+martin%22+killed+indians&lr=&ei=F468SaeVCILKlQS8neDVAg]</ref> Joseph Martin and Betsy Ward had two children.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r-8ABXy1WuMC&pg=PA75&dq=%22general+joseph+martin%22&lr=&ei=YgZ6Se6FDZ-4lATm05nsBg |title=Nancy Ward / Dragging Canoe: Cherokee Chieftainess / Cherokee-Chickamauga War Chief| author= Pat Alderman| date=1978 | ISBN= 0-932807-05-4 |publisher=The Overmountain Press |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref> (Joseph Martin's son by his Cherokee wife was educated in Virginia schools, but afterwards elected to return to the Cherokee.)<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ERA7ZS0RBCAC&pg=PA570&lpg=PA570&dq=%22brice+martin%22+%22joseph+martin%22&source=bl&ots=AJyid5JWgn&sig=8SOYW5D7bUDzrd7V4PqA29wt0IM&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=5&ct=result |title=History of the Cherokee Indians and Their Legends and Folk Lore, Emmet Starr, Reprinted by Genealogical Publishing Company, 2009 |publisher=Google Books |date=October 1, 2004 |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref>
On November 3, 1777, Martin was commissioned by Governor Patrick Henry as Agent and Superintendent for Indian Affairs for the State of Virginia. (Martin served in the same capacity with the state of [[North Carolina]] from 1783 to 1789.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8eFSK4o--M0C&pg=PA612&dq=%22thomas+walker%22+%22joseph+martin%22&lr=&ei=gZ29SZT4HpLakATw_uCDAw |title=The Kentucky Encyclopedia, John E. Kleber, Kentucky Bicentennial Commission, Lowell H. Harrison, Thomas Dionysius Clark, Published by University Press of Kentucky, 1992, ISBN 0-8131-1772-0 |publisher=Google Books |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref>) Gov. Henry instructed Martin that he was "to reside at some place in that Nation in order to negotiate and direct all things relating to the Commonwealth and which concern the interest thereof, using your best endeavors from time to time to preserve peace with that Nation and to cultivate their present good Disposition." It was an appointment Martin would continue to hold until 1789.<ref>[https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://www.geocities.com/genjosmartin/PUSEY.htm&date=2009-10-25+22:34:46 An Unsung Hero of the Virginia Frontier, Dr. William Allen Pusey, The Filson Club, February 3, 1936, geocities.com]</ref>
During his time on the frontier, Martin became acquainted at an early age with two other Revolutionary War patriots and frontiersmen: [[Benjamin Cleveland]], who was his brother-in-law, [They were not related, just lifetime friends. Susannah Graves, the wife of Joseph Martin and Mary Graves the wife of Benjamin Cleveland were second cousins, common ancestor Capt. Thomas Graves. <\ref> Wills of Joseph Graves, Thomas Graves and Benjamin Graves.Grace S. Green] Cleveland having married the sister of Susannah Graves; and [[Thomas Sumter]], who had been a companion of Martin's during his early adventures on the frontier. Both men were fellow Virginia natives who struck out for the wilds, and both were ardent patriots.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gGOSEXzyo-oC&pg=PA240&lpg=PA240&dq=%22thomas+sumter%22+%22joseph+martin%22&source=web&ots=vPdCDyf38P&sig=DMiLHotez-7JbQ-sQtoCrDGRdi8&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=1&ct=result |title=Biographical History of North Carolina from Colonial Times to the Present, Vol. 2, Samuel A'Court Ashe, C. L. Van Noppen, Greensboro, N.C., 1905 |publisher=Google Books |date=September 7, 2005 |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wWYXhh8k_jQC&pg=PA295&lpg=PA295&dq=%22benjamin+cleveland%22+%22joseph+martin%22&source=web&ots=231AsnkEgM&sig=yR-bxge_DF_cduTCcqltkZTLwc8&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=8&ct=result |title=The Dividing Paths: Cherokees and South Carolinians Through the Era of Revolution, Tom Hatley, M. Thomas Hatley, Oxford University Press US, 1993 |publisher=Google Books |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref>
During the [[American Revolutionary War|Revolutionary War]] it was the efforts of Joseph Martin (then a Major) that helped prevent the [[Overhill Cherokee]] from launching widespread attacks on American colonists, which [[Loyalist (American Revolution)|Loyalist]] agents had attempted to incite.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ei0TAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA145&lpg=PA145&dq=%22joseph+martin%22+%22james+madison%22&source=bl&ots=Mn26kyR23X&sig=I-tPYJ-0XYS7wyG9N8gwF4yKjtc&hl=en&ei=h5XGSaqUNYmQtQPs1t3jBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=5&ct=result#PPA570,M1 |title=History of the Cherokee Indians and Their Legends and Folk Lore, Emmet Starr, The Warden Company, Oklahoma City, 1921 |publisher=Google Books |date=October 1, 2004 |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref> Following the British capture of [[Savannah, Georgia|Savannah]] and [[Augusta, Georgia]] in 1778–1779, English goods made their way to the Cherokee on the [[Savannah River]], prompting some tribesmen to rejoin the English cause.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7C6ZJGHLPCIC&pg=PA202&dq=%22patrick+henry%22+%22joseph+martin%22&lr=&ei=gPq_Se31EInAlQSRxNSFCA |title=The American Revolution in Indian country: crisis and diversity in Native American communities, Colin Gordon Calloway, Frederick Hoxie, Neal Salisbury, Cambridge University Press, 1995, ISBN 0-521-47569-4 |publisher=Google Books |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref>
Martin's diplomacy with the Cherokees in 1780–81, wrote the American Historical Association, enabled the [[Continental Army]] to achieve victory over the English at the [[Battle of Kings Mountain]], thus hastening the end of the conflict. On the eve of the [[Battle of Guilford Court House]], in February 1781, General [[Nathanael Greene]] wrote Martin and seven other officers – including [[John Sevier]], [[Arthur Campbell (Virginia)|Arthur Campbell]], and [[William Christian (Virginia)|William Christian]] – appointing them agents to treat with the Cherokees and Chicasaws "to afford the Said Tribes of Indians every mark of our good disposition towards them." Foremost in Greene's thinking, apparently, was keeping the Indians on the sidelines as the [[Continental Army]] and its militia forces fought the British in the last days of the war.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9rkRAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA443&lpg=PA443&dq=%22general+joseph+martin%22&source=bl&ots=7icrtX2uMQ&sig=LZ8ufkfv3AZIzClAOvBZJImX2E4&hl=en&ei=B-PsS8nQLouosgOu0onhDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CDIQ6AEwBTgK#v=onepage&q=%22general%20joseph%20martin%22&f=false |title=Letter from Nathaniel Greene to Joseph Martin, William Christian, William Preston, Arthur Campbell, Robert Sevier, Evan Shelby, Joseph Williams, John Sevier, 26 February 1781, Publications of the Southern History Association, Vol. VIII, Colyer Meriwether (ed.), Published by the Association, Washington, D. C., 1908 |publisher=Google Books |date=November 21, 2007 |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref> Greene was probably mindful of previous British attempts at sending large quantities of ammunition, weapons, horses, cash and goods to their Indian allies through their Florida redoubts.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XWEU0MaU87kC&pg=PA164&lpg=PA164&dq=%22capt.+joseph+martin%22+tennessee&source=bl&ots=SPPz1qqwWi&sig=r943H4BOo_9rbce8heFpuPgjpNs&hl=en&ei=mwTtS9zGF5GuswPOuv2KCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CBkQ6AEwATgU#v=onepage&q=%22capt.%20joseph%20martin%22%20tennessee&f=false |title=The History of Hamilton County and Chattanooga, Tennessee, Vol. 1, Zella Armstrong, The Lookout Publishing Co., Chattanooga, Tn., 1931, ISBN 0-932807-91-7 |publisher=Google Books |date=September 15, 2003 |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref>
At the same time – and complicating Martin's legacy – Martin and his sons were prime movers behind the settlement of [[Tennessee]] by removing obdurate Cherokees from the territory.<ref name =Annual/>
By the end of the Revolution, Martin's place as chief colonial Indian agent seemed secure. In January 1780, [[Governor of Virginia|Virginia governor]] [[Thomas Jefferson]] directed Martin to negotiate with the Cherokees to secure land around a new fort being overseen by General [[George Rogers Clark]] at the mouth of the Ohio River ([[Fort Jefferson (Ohio)|Fort Jefferson]]).<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2SBCAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA385&lpg=PA385&dq=%22joseph+martin%22+%22thomas+jefferson%22&source=bl&ots=n7n19BHaXP&sig=vVXR6hd2o-ntr9vh4uK3O_EU6KY&hl=en&ei=9rmzS9rWK5O4NZzoyPoJ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CBoQ6AEwBzgy#v=onepage&q=%22joseph%20martin%22%20%22thomas%20jefferson%22&f=false |title=George Rogers Clark Papers, 1771–1781|author=George Rogers Clark|editor=[[James Alton James]]|publisher=Illinois State Historical Library|location=Springfield, Illinois|year=1912|accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref> In the fall of 1783, the [[State of Virginia]] built a new fort at the [[Cumberland Gap]], replacing an older fort which was adjudged to lie within the boundaries of [[North Carolina]]. The new Virginia fort was designed as the primary residence for Martin while he was in the region on official business.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DSUSAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA278&dq=%27DANIEL+BOONE%22+%22JOSEPH+MARTIN%27&lr=&ei=7T27SaUdj8CVBM6HmdML#PPA380,M1 |title=History of Southwest Virginia, 1746–1786, Washington County, 1777–1870, Lewis Preston Summers, J. L. Hill Printing Company, Richmond, Virginia, 1903 |publisher=Google Books |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref> And in 1784, [[Thomas Jefferson]] directed Martin to use his connections with the Cherokees to negotiate for more land between the Carolinas and the Mississippi to establish American sovereignty over the region.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jeffersonswest.unl.edu/archive/view_doc.php?id=jef.00025 |title=Letter from Thomas Jefferson to Joseph Martin, 24 January 1780, Jefferson and the Roots of Lewis and Clark, University of Nebraska-Lincoln |publisher=Jeffersonswest.unl.edu |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://home.nps.gov/trte/parkmgmt/upload/Trailword.pdf |title=Historic and Historical Archaeological Resources of the Cherokee Trail of Tears, National Register of Historic Places, National Park Service, United States Department of the Interior |format=PDF |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref>
Later, in a twist overlooked by most historians, Martin corresponded with [[Alexander McGillivray]], the leader of the [[Muscogee Creek|Creek]] Indians, who had [[Loyalist]] sentiments. In 1788 a letter<ref>{{cite web|last1=Martin|first1=Joseph|title=Letter, 1788 Nov. 8, Tugoloe [i.e., Tugaloo] to Alexander McGillory [i.e., McGillivray]|url=http://dlg.galileo.usg.edu/zlna/id:tcc057|website=Southeastern Native American Documents, 1730-1842|publisher=Digital Library of Georgia|accessdate=17 May 2016}}</ref> from Martin to McGillivray was intercepted in which Martin professed to be interested in settling abroad. When the letter was discovered, the [[North Carolina General Assembly]] launched an investigation into Martin's conduct. But he was later exonerated when it turned out that he was acting as a spy on Patrick Henry's instructions to ferret out the nature of McGillivray's ties to the Spanish, who were then active in Florida.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w_n6Cm3qjX0C&pg=PA344&dq=%22joseph+martin%22+%22patrick+henry%22&ei=HJ65SfeGCIjClQTz8sSiBQ#PPA344,M1 |title=The Conquest of the Old Southwest: The Romantic Story of the Early Pioneers Into Virginia, the Carolinas, Tennessee, and Kentucky, 1740–1790, Archibald Henderson, The Century Company, New York, 1920 |publisher=Google Books |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref> [[File:Captain Joseph Martin payroll 1777.jpg|thumb|left|175px|Payroll of [[Continental Army]] forces in [[Washington County, Virginia]], handwritten by Capt. Joseph Martin Jr., 1777]] "General Martin's conduct so far as I could discern in that affair was really praise-worthy," Henry wrote to [[United States Senator]] from Virginia [[Richard Henry Lee]]. "He [Martin] frequently gave me Intelligence of Creek Indian affairs, and of the intercourse between other Indians and the [[Spanish people|Spaniards]] that was interesting.<ref name="WWHv3">{{cite book|last=Henry|first=William Wirt|title=Patrick Henry: Life, Correspondence and Speeches|volume=III|year=2007|origyear=1891: [[Charles Scribner's Sons]], New York|publisher=[[Kessinger Publishing]]|location=[[Whitefish, Montana]]|pages=676|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eB5CAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA409&dq=%22joseph+martin%22+%22patrick+henry%22&ei=lrW5Sf_5Go-qkATYy937Cw#PPA413,M1|ISBN=0548121907|authorlink=William Wirt Henry|accessdate=14 October 2012|format=following link points to results for search term ["Joseph Martin" "Patrick Henry"] in 1891 ed. as archived by Google Books; format: HTML}}</ref>{{rp|413}}
General Martin and Governor Patrick Henry kept a long-running correspondence through the years, some of which concerned real estate speculation. Other letters recounted Martin's dealings with the Indian tribes, as well as settlement efforts in Tennessee.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5hwLAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA28&lpg=PA28&dq=%22joseph+martin%22+%22patrick+henry%22&source=bl&ots=FxCfxmMUlR&sig=Hbj-jyV0kf5TQtmUBMT-fX05wFM&hl=en&ei=LJy5SdnYD5GYsAPB_9w-&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=3&ct=result#PPA28,M1 |title=Letters from Joseph Martin to Patrick Henry, Publications of the Southern History Association, Vol. VI, Published by the Association, Washington, D.C., 1902 |publisher=Google Books |date=May 16, 2006 |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref> As late as 1790, Patrick Henry wrote Joseph Martin concerning a real estate investment, holding out that the hope, Henry noted, that Martin might finally capitalize on his long service to Virginia. "After all the Hazards you have run," Henry wrote, "that you have not acquired so much property as many others would have done in your situation, I was desirous to throw something in your way by which some fine lands would have been offered to you in our purchase." <ref name="WWHv3" />{{rp|409}}
==Career as an Indian agent== [[File:Joseph Martin Henry Lee.gif|thumb|left|175px|Letter from Joseph Martin, Jr. to Virginia Governor [[Henry Lee III|Henry Lee]] discussing [[Powell Valley]], ca 1791]] Ultimately, General Martin lost his appointment as chief Indian agent. Martin's "manner of treating with the Indians necessarily prevented his appointment," Senator Richard Henry Lee informed Patrick Henry in September 1789. "At present no such office as a standing Indian agent is appointed. The Government of the Western Territory is charged with such affairs."<ref name="WWHv3" />{{rp|404}}
In some quarters Martin was seen as too lenient with the Indians, especially after an incident in 1786<ref>The previous year, in April 1785, Patrick Henry first warned Joseph Martin that the encroachment of settlers of the secessionist [[State of Franklin]], by usurping Cherokee lands without payment, was upsetting arrangements previously reached between the state of Virginia and the tribe. [https://books.google.com/books?id=eB5CAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA409&dq=%22joseph+martin%22+%22patrick+henry%22&ei=lrW5Sf_5Go-qkATYy937Cw#PPA294,M1]</ref> when several young Cherokee warriors were said to have murdered two white settlers near [[Clinch Mountain]]. The killings set off calls for retribution within the [[secessionist]] State of Franklin, and Martin found himself trying to mediate the dispute, and calm the settlers, while trying to prevent the angry Cherokees from joining with the Creeks.<ref>Early in the creation of the [[State of Franklin]], Joseph Martin had been elected by the Franklin Council to serve on the new colony's [[Privy Council]], but Martin wrote Henry that he had rejected the post, thinking that it would conflict with his duties as a Virginia agent to the Indians.[https://books.google.com/books?id=FpcLAAAAIAAJ&pg=RA1-PA275&dq=%22patrick+henry%22+%22joseph+martin%22&lr=&ei=zf-_ScKyC5DSkwSRqYmwCQ]</ref> Martin did little to disguise his contempt for the authorities of the State of Franklin, who, Martin wrote Henry, "immediately marched into the above mentioned Town, where they killed one Young [Indian] woman, and Shot Several others."<ref name="WWHv3" />{{rp|373}}
But Martin himself had not hesitated to wield military power against the Cherokees, especially when they killed several colonists at the instigation of Loyalist and English agents during the Revolution. In 1781, following a running battle between Indian forces and those of the colonists, [[Colonel]] [[Arthur Campbell (Virginia)|Arthur Campbell]],<ref>[[Campbell County, Tennessee]] was named for Virginia legislator Arthur Campbell.</ref> [[Lieutenant Colonel]] [[John Sevier]] and Martin addressed a letter to the Indian chiefs, warning them about their actions. "You know you began the war," the bulletin began, "by listening to the bad councils of the [[King of England]] and the falsehoods told you by his agents." Further hostilities, the three colonial leaders warned, would result in a military campaign against the Indian villages.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DSUSAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA278&dq=%27DANIEL+BOONE%22+%22JOSEPH+MARTIN%27&lr=&ei=7T27SaUdj8CVBM6HmdML#PPA346,M1 |title=History of Southwest Virginia, 1746–1786, Washington County, 1777–1870, Lewis Preston Summers, J. L. Hill Printing Company, Richmond, Virginia, 1903 |publisher=Google Books |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref> Seven years later, in 1788, Martin again fought the Overmountain [[Cherokee]], as well as the [[Chickamauga Cherokee]], in a battle at [[Lookout Mountain]], during the [[Cherokee–American wars]].<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oehdFaphbYoC&pg=RA2-PA286&lpg=RA2-PA286&dq=%22joseph+martin%22+tennessee+general+assembly&source=bl&ots=EHv1KqvDtc&sig=b2zu5MdD-mv0JBVt2X_mfvZ46hA&hl=en&ei=apS8SZ21EZKWsQOXu4yeAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=5&ct=result#PPA121,M1 |title=The History of Hamilton County and Chattanooga, Tennessee, Vol. II, Zella Armstrong, The Overmountain Press, 1993, ISBN 0-932807-99-2 |publisher=Google Books |date=September 15, 2003 |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref>
But having eventually struck a hard-won peace with the tribes, Martin bridled at the actions of the [[State of Franklin]]. Henry empathized with Martin, writing the General in May 1785 that "the disorderly behavior of the Franklin people, as they call themselves, gives me concern. If they will not be subservient to the Rules and Regulations respecting Indian affairs, which prevail in all the States, they must expect none of the advantages of the Union."<ref>Henry, Martin and others saw the conduct of the State of Franklin settlers, who urged secession from the new union, as endangering much of what had been accomplished on the frontier. They also saw it in economic terms as driving a wedge between the newly created states and perhaps encouraging encroachment by the always-feared Spanish interests, especially on the Mississippi and in the western territories. As large land speculators, this fear was probably uppermost in the minds of many Virginia gentry.[https://books.google.com/books?id=eB5CAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA409&dq=%22joseph+martin%22+%22patrick+henry%22&ei=lrW5Sf_5Go-qkATYy937Cw#PPA374,M1]</ref>
"Partisans of the State in N[orth] Carolina afterwards found him obnoxious to their views," former Governor Henry wrote Virginia Senator [[William Grayson]] in urging Martin's reappointment in 1789, "and as I believe often endangered his Life For his duty called him to discourage their Disorderly conduct [and] thwart their favorite Schemes." Henry then commended Martin for his efforts to impose restraints upon the actions of the State of Franklin settlers, whose "frequent Butcherys of Indians & Refinement in cruelty sufficiently characterize these people who are Mr Martins decided Foes."<ref name="books.google.com">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i5RADFeMCg8C&pg=PA202&dq=%22patrick+henry%22+%22joseph+martin%22&lr=&ei=7QTASduzMpvukQSQsKDwCw |title=The Virginia Magazine of History and Biography, Vol. XIV-No. 1, Virginia Historical Society, Richmond, Virginia, 1906 |publisher=Google Books |date=May 1, 2009 |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref>
[[File:Happy While United colonial medal.jpg|thumb|right|220px|''Happy While United'', bronze medals struck by [[State of Virginia]] in 1780, carried by Martin for distribution to Cherokee allies of Virginia colonists fighting British rule]] Martin's attempts to restrain the [[State of Franklin]] settlers from a more-belligerent course made Martin unacceptable in some quarters, where he was seen as too 'soft' on the tribesmen.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Martin|first1=Joseph|title=[Letter] 1785 Sept. 19, Chotee [i.e., Chota ?] to Gov[ernor of North Carolina, Richard] Caswell|url=http://dlg.galileo.usg.edu/zlna/id:ch013|website=Southeastern Native American Documents, 1730-1842|publisher=Digital Library of Georgia|accessdate=17 May 2016}}</ref> Martin also became controversial in some quarters are the [[Treaty of Hopewell]] in 1785, when Martin, [[Andrew Pickens (congressman)|Andrew Pickens]] and [[Benjamin Hawkins]], acting as government agents, concluded treaties with the Cherokees and the Choctaws. The Cherokee treaty particularly engendered later enmity from the Indian signatories, as well as the colonial state governments. The Indians saw the treaty as a thinly-veiled land grab, and the state governments saw the treaty as an attempt to encroach on local government authority, and attempts were made in [[United States Congress|Congress]] to void it. "No action of Martin's life brought down on him more condemnation than this [the Hopewell Treaty]," wrote historian Stephen B. Weeks of the incident.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gGOSEXzyo-oC&pg=PR10&lpg=PR10&dq=%22joseph+martin%22+%22thomas+jefferson%22&source=bl&ots=vPixDB826K&sig=Z7koXYwkWX5JWybeb7hqNVlHJJA&hl=en&ei=vsGzS7WjHJHYNaOEwJsJ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CAUQ6AEwADhk#v=onepage&q=%22joseph%20martin%22%20&f=false |title=Joseph Martin, Stephen B. Weeks, Biographical History of North Carolina from Colonial Times to the Present, Vol. II, Samuel A'Court Ashe (ed.), Charles L. Van Noppen Publisher, Greensboro, N.C., 1905 |publisher=Google Books |date=September 7, 2005 |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref>
Consequently, his appointment as agent was not renewed, despite Henry's repeated entreaties to political allies for Martin's reinstatement. (In a 1789 letter to Senator William Grayson, Henry reminded his political ally that Martin had been so effective in his Indian dealings during the Revolutionary War that British agents had offered rewards to their Indian allies for Martin's scalp.<ref name="books.google.com"/>)
But the forces allied against Martin overwhelmed Henry's defense, and in 1789, his career as Indian agent finished, General Martin sold his large holdings in the [[Powell River (Tennessee River)|Powell's Valley]] and near [[Cumberland Gap]] and returned to his lands in Henry County next door to Henry's<ref>"His wife and Family are my neighbours at Leatherwood & I can forward any letter to him," former Governor Henry wrote to [[United States Senator]] from Virginia [[William Grayson]] in 1789.[https://books.google.com/books?id=i5RADFeMCg8C&pg=PA202&dq=%22patrick+henry%22+%22joseph+martin%22&lr=&ei=7QTASduzMpvukQSQsKDwCw#PPA203,M1]</ref> to spend the rest of his life.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~vahsswv/historicalsketches/martingenjoseph.html |title=General Joseph Martin, A Forgotten Pioneer, 1740–1808, Gordon Aronhime, Southwest Virginia Historical Society, ancestry.com |publisher=Rootsweb.ancestry.com |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref> A year later, in 1790, when the governorship of the [[Southwest Territory]] opened up, Patrick Henry suggested Gen. Martin, along with [[George Mason]], for the job, but both were passed over in favor of [[William Blount]].<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9McNQm27VmUC&pg=PA88&lpg=PA88&dq=%22general+joseph+martin%22+mason&source=bl&ots=q6z-c4dB5g&sig=Y77kYC9zp31c4iEuqB40fA07l40&hl=en&ei=UwRaTKy0NJDWtQOS0uTUDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CCsQ6AEwBTgK#v=onepage&q=%22general%20joseph%20martin%22%20mason&f=false |title=Tennessee: A Short History, Robert Ewing Corlew, Stanley John Folmsbee, Enoch L. Mitchell, The University of Tennessee Press, Knoxville, 1981, ISBN 0-87049-647-6 |publisher=Google Books |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref> [[File:George Washington George Walton letter.jpg|thumb|right|175px|Letter from [[George Washington]] to Georgia Governor [[George Walton]] expressing Washington's disapproval of Martin's performance as agent for the [[Cherokee]], 1789]]
Later Judgments on Martin's career as an Indian agent have been mixed. Writing in 1894, [[Theodore Roosevelt]] called Martin "a firm friend of the red race, [who] had earnestly striven to secure justice for them."<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=FHcOAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA321&lpg=PA321&dq=%22general+joseph+martin%22+knox&source=bl&ots=SG0gOrfymG&sig=VVb3G92503J9D37KDZS58vvea9E&hl=en&ei=A0TvS4_4PIX2sgPvlej0Dw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBUQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=%22general%20joseph%20martin%22%20knox&f=false The Winning of the West: The Founding of the Trans-Alleghany Commonwealths 1784–1790, Vol. 3, [[Theodore Roosevelt]], G. P. Putnam's Sons, New York, 1894]</ref>
==Legislative service== In his peripatetic life on the frontier, Martin was called upon to serve in the legislatures of several states. He served as a member of the [[North Carolina]] Convention called to approve the [[United States Constitution]], and served several times in the [[North Carolina General Assembly]]. Martin was subsequently elected to the [[Virginia House of Delegates]], until he finally chose to retire because of advanced age.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DSUSAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA278&dq=%27DANIEL+BOONE%22+%22JOSEPH+MARTIN%27&lr=&ei=7T27SaUdj8CVBM6HmdML#PPA749,M1 |title=History of Southwest Virginia, 1746–1786, Washington County, 1777–1870, Lewis Preston Summers, J. L. Hill Printing Company, Richmond, Virginia, 1903 |publisher=Google Books |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref> (In 1787 the North Carolina assembly chose Martin as Brigadier General of the Washington District.) During his time in the Virginia legislature, Martin was one of the primary supporters of [[James Madison]]'s [[Kentucky and Virginia Resolutions]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.josephmartinchapter.org/josephmartin.html |title=Biography of Joseph Martin, General Joseph Martin Chapter, Tennessee Society of the Sons of the American Revolution |publisher=Josephmartinchapter.org |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref> During his military service in [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], Martin was elected to the Georgia legislature in 1783.
Martin was also initially a member of the [[Watauga Association]], which supported the founding of the State of Franklin. Martin subsequently resigned his membership when he saw that it might compromise his role as Indian agent.
In 1799, Martin and his old friend Major John Redd of Henry County served as the two county representatives on the Virginia commission relating to the [[Alien and Sedition Acts]].<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cMPyo8TrY-IC&pg=PA235&lpg=PA235&dq=%22joseph+martin%22+%22thomas+jefferson%22&source=bl&ots=1oVQdcq2u4&sig=YZFu0ukQaLhlU-IKWeWBqKXexTg&hl=en&ei=yM6zS821OpWINv3woJEJ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CA0Q6AEwAjhu#v=onepage&q=&f=false |title=The Virginia Report of 1799–1800 Touching the Alien and Sedition Laws; Together with the Virginia Resolutions of December 21, 1799, Originally published by J.W. Randolph, Richmond, 1850, Reprinted by the Lawbook Exchange Ltd., Clark, New Jersey, 2004 |publisher=Google Books |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref>
==Family life, legacy, and descendants== Gen. Joseph Martin, Jr.'s first wife was Sarah Lucas. They were both born in Virginia and together had five children, including Revolutionary War officer, Col. William L. Martin, who eventually moved to Smith County, in Middle Tennessee.
After Sarah Lucas Martin's death, Joseph Martin, Jr. married Susannah Graves in Henry County, Virginia. They had 12 children, all of whom were born in Virginia, including: Col. Joseph Martin of Henry County, Va. He was one of five of Gen. Martin's sons who served in the [[War of 1812]].
Another Martin son, and veteran of the War of 1812, was Patrick Henry Martin. He was a young, trained lawyer, and died a bachelor on his trip home after the war. He was named in honor of Gen. Martin's friend and neighbor, Governor Patrick Henry. Gen. Martin's son, Capt. Lewis Graves Martin, also a veteran of the War of 1812, moved from Henry County, Virginia to Rutherford/Cannon County in Middle Tennessee, in 1816, where he married Belinda Rucker (daughter of Gideon Rucker, Sr. & Joyce Reade; both of whom were born in Va. and moved to Middle Tennessee). They had a large family before Belinda's death in the late 1830s. Capt. Lewis G. Martin remarried and removed to Missouri in 1840. Another Martin son, and veteran of the War of 1812, was Thomas Martin. He also moved to Middle Tennessee where he married Georgia Carr (daughter of Dabney Carr). Alexander Martin, another son and veteran of the War of 1812, also moved to Middle Tennessee. He married Elizabeth Carr (daughter of John Fyndall Carr, also a Tennessean from Virginia), and after some years, moved to Missouri. Another son of Gen. Martin and Susannah Graves was Esq. Judge John C. Martin, who also moved to Middle Tennessee in the days following the War of 1812, where he became a judge and chairman of the Cannon County courts, and served five terms as county executive. He was also responsible for the construction of the original Cannon County court house, erected in 1830. He married Sophia Rucker, sister to his brother Lewis' wife, Belinda.
Other children of Gen. Martin include: Martha Martin Cleveland, Elizabeth Martin Waller (1768 - 1805), Brice Martin (1770 - 1856), Jesse Martin (1786 - 1836), and Susan Martin King (1799 - 1867).
Gen. Martin also had two children with his half-[[Cherokee]], [[common-law marriage|common law wife]] ("frontier wife"), Elizabeth Ward, daughter of frontiersman Bryant Ward and his wife Nancy, "the beloved woman of the Cherokee." One of their children may have been Nancy Martin Hildebrand (1778 - 1837).
The Native Indian connection of two members of the Martin family has created some confusion for some Martin genealogy researchers; Gen. Joseph Martin's brother, Capt. John "Jack" Calvin Martin, Sr., of his N.C. Rock House Plantation, a.k.a. Rock Castle Plantation, is often confused with his brother Gen. Joseph Martin. Capt. John "Jack" Martin, Sr. moved from Virginia to N.C. with his brother William Martin, Sr.. In N.C. Capt. John "Jack" Martin, Sr. married a Miss Emory, who was half Native American. She died early in their marriage. Her widower, "Jack," then married her sister, a second Miss Emory. This same Capt. John "Jack" Martin, Sr. and his Emory wife were the parents of a John Calvin Martin, Jr. who served as a judge on the supreme court of the Cherokee Nation in Oklahoma, although he was only 1/4 Cherokee. This Oklahoma judge was the older cousin of the Tennessee judge of the same name; the son of Gen. Joseph Martin and wife Susannah Graves, as mentioned earlier; Esq. Judge, John C. Martin of Tennessee. There were two Martin cousins with the same name who both served as judges. Although they were born many miles and many years apart, their identities are sometimes confused by modern researchers looking at the names alone.
Another brother of Gen. Joseph Martin, William Martin, Sr., was the father of Gen. William "Buck" Martin, Jr., who served in the War of 1812 on Andrew Jackson's staff.
Gen. Martin, after helping adjudicate the western boundary line between [[North Carolina]], [[Kentucky]], and Virginia as far as the [[Cumberland Mountains]], retired to his plantation ''Belmont'' on [[Leatherwood Creek (Virginia)|Leatherwood Creek]], which he had purchased in 1796 from [[Benjamin Harrison V]] of [[Berkeley Plantation]], which was originally built by a Capt. John Martin who was possibly the great-uncle of General Joseph Martin. General Joseph Martin died at his plantation on December 18, 1808, and was buried there in the family cemetery.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=99ERAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA113|title=Reminiscences of Western Virginia, Major John Redd, The Virginia Magazine of History and Biography, Vol. VII, Virginia Historical Society, Richmond, Va., 1899 |publisher=Google Books |date=May 1, 2009 |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref><ref>[https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://www.geocities.com/genjosmartin/cemetery1.html&date=2009-10-25+22:34:52 The Martin Family Cemetery on Belmont(e) Plantation, geocities.com]</ref> Buried in the family graveyard are three other Joseph Martins: [[Colonel]] Joseph Martin, son of the general, his son Joseph, and his grandson Joseph, who lived at ''Greenwood'' plantation.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w3f7i_buckMC&pg=PA213&lpg=PA213&dq=%22joseph+martin%22+albemarle+county&source=bl&ots=R9KuWTlFV3&sig=-Z-ujkPnmEbndunZDIc4m26h55w&hl=en&ei=XnTVSsH5K5H6sQOx_8TaAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CCAQ6AEwBjge#v=onepage&q=&f=false |title=Tennessee Records: Tombstone Inscriptions and Manuscripts, Jeannette Tillotson Acklen, Reprinted by Heritage Books, 2007, ISBN 978-0-7884-2144-0 |publisher=Google Books |date=June 1, 1980 |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref>[[File:Colonel William Martin.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Col. William Martin, son of General Joseph Martin]]
Initially known as Henry Courthouse, the town of [[Martinsville, Virginia]], was later renamed in honor of this early soldier, planter, pioneer, and real estate speculator.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R3gnID3Wv_IC&pg=PA91&dq=%22general+joseph+martin%22&lr=&ei=rzx6ScGhGIzSlQSYm9nXBg#PPA93,M1 |title=A History of Henry County, Virginia, with Biographical Sketches of Its Most Prominent Citizens, Judith Parks America Hill, Reissued by Heritage Books, Inc., 2003, ISBN 0-7884-2302-9 |publisher=Google Books |date=January 15, 2006 |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref> For many years afterwards, General Martin remained an obscure figure, until [[Lyman Draper]] began collecting reminiscences about him, including those of Major John Redd, a prominent [[Henry County, Virginia|Henry County]] planter who served under Martin, and who also wrote about his early recollections of General [[Nathanael Greene]], [[George Rogers Clark]], [[Daniel Boone]], Col. [[Benjamin Cleveland]], Dr. [[John Walker (Virginia)|John Walker]], and other early prominent Virginia figures.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mrQZAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA58&dq=%27DANIEL+BOONE%22+%22JOSEPH+MARTIN%27&lr=&ei=Ihy7SY29OIr8lQSQ9c25Cw |title=Descriptive List of Manuscripts Collections of the State Historical Society of |publisher=Google Books |date=October 4, 2006 |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref>
Martin's descendants include his eldest son Col. William Martin,<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vdQRAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA443&lpg=PA443&dq=%22col.+william+martin%22+tennessee&source=bl&ots=PVDuwvy0Ib&sig=Zv7RlMoqLb5MJ3fFb26ED0UuPdQ&hl=en&ei=rH-5SeqsEZLIMtKJzZcI&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=6&ct=result |title=Publications of the Southern History Association, Vol. IV, Published by the Association, Washington, D.C. 1900 |publisher=Google Books |date=November 26, 2007 |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref> Tennessee pioneer,<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zV4oAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA240&dq=%22william+martin%22+%22joseph+martin%22+killed+indians&ei=doy8Sc3UMI_GlQSruPyADA |title=William Martin, The National Cyclopaedia of American Biography, Vol. VII, James T. White & Company, New York, 1897 |publisher=Google Books |date=June 17, 2008 |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref> and member of the [[South Carolina General Assembly|South Carolina]] and [[Georgia General Assembly|Georgia]] legislatures;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~tnsmith/oldpics/martinwilliam.htm |title=Col. William Martin, rootsweb.com |publisher=Rootsweb.ancestry.com |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~tnsmith/cempics/martinwillcem.htm |title=Col. Joseph Martin, member of the [[Virginia House of Delegates]], the [[Virginia State Senate]] and the [[Virginia Constitutional Convention of 1829–1830|Virginia Constitutional Convention]] 1829–1830;<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R3gnID3Wv_IC&pg=PA224&dq=%22patrick+henry%22+%22joseph+martin%22&lr=&ei=bve_SZKfAoyokAShn4nKBQ |title=A History of Henry County, Virginia, Judith Parks America Hill, Originally published 1925, Reprinted by Heritage Books |publisher=Google Books |date=January 15, 2006 |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref> daughter Martha Martin, who was the 1st wife of William Cleveland, son of John (Preacher John) Cleveland, Jr., brother of Benjamin Cleveland, hero of the [[Battle of King's Mountain]]; William Cleveland was a nephew of Benjamin Cleveland; son Major Brice Martin, Tennessee pioneer and [[Surveying|surveyor]] in 1801 of the disputed boundary between Virginia and Tennessee;.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DSUSAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA278dq=%27DANIEL+BOONE%22+%22JOSEPH+MARTIN%27&lr=&ei=7T27SaUdj8CVBM6HmdML#PPA711,M1 |title=History of Southwest Virginia, 1746–1786, Washington County, 1777–1870, Lewis Preston Summers, J. Also descended from Martin was [[Henry Smith Pritchett]], an educator born in [[Missouri]] who served as president of the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]], and Rod D. Martin, former [[PayPal Mafia|PayPal]] executive, former President of the [[National Federation of Republican Assemblies]], technology entrepreneur and author.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dr. Rod Martin to Speak at 2015 Commencement|url=http://www.hlg.edu/newsinfo/news-story.php?id=1426/|publisher=Hannibal LaGrange University|accessdate=13 January 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160117162021/http://www.hlg.edu/newsinfo/news-story.php?id=1426%2F|archivedate=January 17, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
==Toby's freedom== General Joseph Martin, Jr. [[History of slavery in Virginia|owned a slave]] named 'Toby' from the time Toby was about 25 years old, and in his letters to historian [[Lyman Draper]], Martin's son Col. William Martin told Draper that Toby, "a bright mulatto, a little under middle stature, of great physical powers, as well as mental" had served his father for many years and had distinguished himself in several battles. It was General Martin's intention, noted his son, that Toby [[Manumission|be freed]] at Joseph Martin's death, but the General died [[intestate]].
Taking note of the General's affection for his longtime servant, as well as the Martin's family members' sentiments toward Martin's constant companion, the family elected "by mutual consent" to leave Toby out of the inventory of General Martin's [[Estate (law)|estate]], and Toby "has ever since been free, and has made himself a good estate."<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vdQRAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA443&lpg=PA443&dq=%22joseph+martin%22+tennessee+general+assembly&source=bl&ots=PVDvovvYQ9&sig=uZx4aJxTeYFMn9fC-X9MBuxH2O0&hl=en&ei=8n-8SfyWHZnMsAPMnY2eAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=2&ct=result#PPA446,M1 |title=Publications of the Southern History Association, Vol. IV, Published by the Association, Washington, D. C., 1900 |publisher=Google Books |date=November 26, 2007 |accessdate=November 28, 2011}}</ref> In his letter to Draper, Col. William Martin calls the freed slave "my fine old brother Toby."
==Recent monument== On June 27–29, 2008, 200 descendants of General Joseph Martin gathered in the city named for him to unveil a monument in his honor, at the Gen. Joseph Martin, Jr. Bicentennial Celebration.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.martinsvillebulletin.com/news/local/monument-placed-in-martin-s-honor/article_1ebaa659-5992-59ad-8597-bb911affe3f2.html |title=Monument placed in Martin's honor, The Martinsville Bulletin, June 29, 2008 |publisher=Martinsvillebulletin.com |date=June 29, 2008 |accessdate=November 28, 2011 }}</ref>

It owns [[luxury goods]] brands, including [[Gucci]], [[Yves Saint Laurent (brand)|Yves Saint Laurent]], [[Balenciaga]], [[Alexander McQueen (brand)|Alexander McQueen]], [[Bottega Veneta]], [[Boucheron]] and [[Brioni (fashion)|Brioni]], [[Pomellato]]. The company was founded in 1963. It was known as '''Pinault S.A.''' until 1994, as '''Pinault-Printemps-Redoute''' from 1994 to 2005, as '''PPR''' from 2005 to 2013, and became Kering in 2013. It has been quoted on [[Euronext Paris]] since 1988 and has been a constituent of the [[CAC 40]] index since 1995. The company has been headed by [[François-Henri Pinault]] since 2005. == History == === Building a retail empire with wood === In 1963, with a loan from his family and a bank, [[François Pinault]] opened the ''Établissements Pinault'' in [[Brittany]] (France) and specialized in timber trading. The company grew organically and through successful acquisitions. In 1988, Pinault S.A. was listed on the [[Paris Stock Exchange]], multiplying the group’s financial power. In 1989, it purchased 20% of [[CFAO]], a French distribution conglomerate active throughout [[Africa]]. In 1990, Pinault S.A. and CFAO merged, and François Pinault became head of the newly formed group. This accelerated its acquisitions in the retail sector: [[Conforama]] (French furniture retailer) in 1991, [[Printemps]] (department stores in Paris) in 1992, which also owned 54% of [[La Redoute]] (French mail-order shopping retailer), and [[Fnac]] (French bookstore, multimedia and electronics retailer) in 1994. To align the group’s identity with its new activities, it was renamed Pinault-Printemps-Redoute (PPR) in 1994. === Offloading retail assets to invest in luxury === [[File:PPR SA.svg|thumb|right|Former logo of the company, when it was known as PPR (Pinault-Printemps-Redoute)]] In 1999, Pinault-Printemps-Redoute purchased a controlling 42% stake of the [[Gucci group]] for $3 billion.{{cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/1999/05/27/europe/gucci/|title=Gucci fades on court ruling|website=Cnn.com|date=27 May 1999|accessdate=24 July 2017}} Through the Gucci deal, Pinault-Printemps-Redoute also acquired the brand [[Yves Saint Laurent (brand)|Yves Saint Laurent]].{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1999/mar/20/business/fi-19096|title=Gucci Group Agrees to Sell 40% Stake to French Retailer|website=Latimes.com|date=20 March 1999|accessdate=24 July 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/business/1999/11/16/gucci-to-buy-parent-of-yves-saint-laurent/1971b749-2e0c-448f-86b3-57dd492b6999/|title=Gucci to Buy Parent Of Yves Saint Laurent|website=Washingtonpost.com|date=16 November 1999|author=Sri Ramakrishnan|accessdate=24 July 2017}} It confirmed this new strategy with its following acquisitions, which included the French high-jewelry house [[Boucheron]] (2000), the Italian leather goods maker [[Bottega Veneta]], and the fashion house [[Balenciaga]] (2001). In 2001, Pinault-Printemps-Redoute also signed strategic partnerships with ex-[[Givenchy]] fashion designer [[Alexander McQueen]] and with [[Stella McCartney]].{{cite book |last1=McNeil |first1=Peter |last2=Riello |first2=Giorgio |date=19 May 2016 |title=Luxury: A Rich History |trans-title= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EsowDAAAQBAJ |language= |location= |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=9780191640278|page=256}} With a new strategy for the group, Pinault-Printemps-Redoute offloaded its assets in the retail sector one after the other: Pinault Bois et Matériaux, upon which the whole group developed and grew, was acquired in 2003 by the British group [[Wolseley plc|Wolseley]].{{cite web|url=http://citywire.co.uk/money/ooh-la-la-wolseley-gets-heavy-in-france/a247731|title=Ooh la la, Wolseley gets heavy in France|website=Citywire.co.uk|date=24 April 2003|author=Joanne Wallen|accessdate=24 July 2017}} In 2003, François Pinault handed over the helm of [[Groupe Artémis|Artémis]], the family holding company that controlled Pinault-Printemps-Redoute and other assets ([[Château Latour]], [[Christie’s]], etc.), to his son François-Henri. In 2004, Pinault-Printemps-Redoute acquired almost all of the remaining shares of the [[Gucci group]] to reach a 99.4% ownership of the Italian luxury company.{{cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2004/03/23/ppr-moves-to-buy-last-30-of-gucci-group/|title=PPR moves to buy last 30% of Gucci Group|website=Nypost.com|date=23 March 2004|author=Suzanne Kapner|accessdate=24 July 2017}} In 2005, François-Henri Pinault chose a hands-on approach to managing Pinault-Printemps-Redoute and decided to take over the position of CEO.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/15/t-magazine/the-man-behind-the-curtain.html|title=The Man Behind the Curtain|website=Nytimes.com|date=15 February 2013|author=Joshua Levine|accessdate=24 July 2017}} The group officially changed its name to PPR. The divestment of the group’s retail assets continued: Le Printemps (2006),{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/06/20/business/worldbusiness/20iht-ppr.html|title=As sales fall, PPR works to unload Printemps|website=Nytimes.com|date=20 June 2006|author=Sara Gay Forden, Jacqueline Simmons|accessdate=24 July 2017}} Conforama (2011), CFAO and Fnac (2012), and La Redoute (2013). committed to defending women’s dignity and rights by combating violence against women and promoting women’s empowerment. Since 2009, the Foundation initiated 47 partnerships with NGOs and supported many social projects oriented towards women’s rights. Many brands have their own philanthropic projects with the support of the Kering Foundation. Gucci launched its project ''Chime for Change'', an international campaign to raise funds for women’s emancipation, focusing on education, health and justice.{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/02/28/chime-for-change-campaign-beyonce-help-girls-run-the-world_n_2784192.html |title=Chime For Change Campaign, Beyoncé Launch Initiative To Help Girls Run The World |publisher=huffingtonpost.com |date= 2013-01-03|accessdate=2013-01-03}} Every year since 2012, the Kering Foundation has contributed to the ''[[International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women]]'' with the ''White Ribbon for Women'' campaign.{{cite web|url=http://www.gq-magazine.co.uk/article/white-ribbon-campaign-women|title=Why you should support the White Ribbon campaign|website=Gq-magazine.co.uk|date=18 November 2016|author=Josh Lee|accessdate=24 July 2017}} === Women In Motion Awards === In 2015, Kering became an official partner of the [[Cannes Film Festival]] and launched ''Women in Motion'' to highlight the contribution of women to the film industry, both in front of and behind the camera. The program is based on talks where personalities share their recommendations for the advancement of women’s representation in the industry. The Women in Motion Awards have been awarded annually to an inspirational figure who embodies the role of women in the film industry, and another to a promising name in cinema.{{cite web|url=https://www.businessoffashion.com/community/companies/kering/portfolio/album/1589948400053818|title=Women in Motion - Cannes International Film Festival|website=Businessoffashion.com|accessdate=20 June 2018}} Past winners include: * 2015 - [[Jane Fonda]], [[Megan Ellison]] * 2016 - [[Geena Davis]], [[Susan Sarandon]] * 2017 - [[Isabelle Huppert]], [[Maysaloun Hamoud]] (Young Talents Award){{cite web|url= http://www.ikonlondonmagazine.com/kering-the-festival-de-cannes-will-present-the-2017-women-in-motion-award-to-isabelle-huppert | title= Kering & The Festival De Cannes Will Present The 2017 Women in Motion Award to Isabelle Huppert | publisher=Ikon London Magazine | date=5 May 2017 | accessdate=23 February 2018}} * 2018 - [[Patty Jenkins]]{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2018/film/news/wonder-woman-patty-jenkins-to-receive-the-2018-women-in-motion-award-1202798608/|title=‘Wonder Woman’ Director Patty Jenkins to Receive 2018 Women in Motion Award|website=Variety.com|date=4 May 2018|author=Stewart Clarke|accessdate=20 June 2018}} == Controversies == === Tax evasion by Marco Bizzarri === In 2018 a network of international journalists, the European Investigative Collaborations (EIC), received leaked documents that provide insight into Kerings tax evasion strategies. The CEO of Gucci, Marco Bizzarri, by contract received a net salary of 8 million Euros. To pay as little tax as possible for this salary a special strategy was formed by Kering. That included a residence in Switzerland and two contracts for Bizzarri, one in Italy and one in Luxemburg. The salary was then paid by a shell corporation in Luxemburg. Using this strategy € 9,49 million gross gained Bizzarri € 8,04 net income.http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/gucci-chef-marco-bizzarri-mogelte-millionengehalt-an-der-steuer-vorbei-a-1190037.html In a statement Kering said that it's methods were within given laws.https://www.reuters.com/article/us-kering-gucci-tax/kering-says-gucci-boss-tax-compliant-in-italy-after-report-idUSKBN1FF2SN === Possible tax evasion === In November 2017 Italian authorities opened a criminal investigation into a tax case involving Kering and its flagship brand Gucci. The inquiry included a raid on Gucci offices in Florence and Milan. The authorities were looking into whether Gucci should have paid as much as 1.3 billion Euro in past domestic taxes.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/21/business/kering-gucci-tax-investigation.html|title=kering-gucci-tax-investigation|website=nytimes.com|date=16 March 2018|accessdate=13 October 2018}} Including France and UK, the amount of possible tax evasion by Kering is considered to be up to 2.5 billion Euros.{{cite web|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/evasion-fiscale/article/2018/03/16/le-groupe-francais-de-luxe-kering-aurait-soustrait-2-5-milliards-d-euros-d-impots-selon-mediapart_5272324_4862750.html|title=le-groupe-francais-de-luxe-kering-aurait-soustrait-2-5-milliards-d-euros-d-impots-selon-mediapart|website=lemonde.fr|date=21
